</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>contrast</b> <i>verb</i> [transitive] to compare two things, situations etc, in order to show how they are different from each other:
<ul>
	<li>In her novel she <b>contrasts</b> the lives of two families in very different circumstances.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>make / draw a distinction between</b> to say that you think two things are very different:
<ul>
	<li>It is important to make a distinction between people's fears about crime and the real situation.</li>
	<li>The author draws a distinction between allowing death to occur, and causing it.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<p align="left"><b>STUDY NOTE: Grammar </b></p>
<p align="left"><b>Draw a distinction</b> is more formal than <b>make a distinction</b>.</p>
<p align="left"></p>

<h1>Concluding</h1>
<h2>Concluding</h2>
<ol>
	<li>What you say when concluding your essay or argument</li>
	<li>Saying again what your aims were at the conclusion of an essay</li>
</ol>
<p align="left"></p>
<p align="left"><b><i>1. What you say when concluding your essay or argument </i></b></p>
<b>in conclusion</b> a phrase used at the beginning of the final paragraph of an essay or article, when you want to write about the main things that you have mentioned in it:
<ul>
	<li><b>In conclusion</b>, the results of our study suggest that this type of diet is perfectly safe.</li>
	<li>Thus, <b>in conclusion</b>, the population of England remained fairly stable for much of the 15th century.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>to summarize / to sum up</b> used when referring to the main things that you have mentioned in it:
<ul>
	<li><b>To summarize:</b> there are many reasons why people commit crime.</li>
	<li><b>To sum up,</b> in 1922 the Soviet government found itself in a situation similar to the one faced by the Tsars.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<p align="left"><b>STUDY NOTE: Grammar </b></p>
You use <b>to</b> <b>summarize</b> and <b>to sum up</b> at the start of the final paragraph of an essay or article. They can be followed either by a colon or a comma.
<p align="left"></p>
<b>something can be summarized as follows</b> used when saying what you think the main points about something are:
<ul>
	<li>The organization's main aim <b>can be summarized as follows</b>: to create opportunities for students to learn a wide range of computer skills.</li>
	<li>The result of the survey <b>can be summarized as follows.</b> Both Japan and Korea show a strong preference for natural gas over oil, coal, and nuclear energy.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>the following conclusion(s) may be drawn</b> used when you want to mention something that you think is true because of what has been written earlier in the article or essay:
<ul>
	<li><b>The following conclusions may be drawn</b> from these figures. Firstly, the US economy is moving out of recession. Secondly, there are no grounds for concern about its immediate future.</li>
	<li>With regard to defense measures against attack from the air, <b>the following conclusions may be drawn.</b> The best method of defense is a strong air force. The next requirement is a well-organized observation (radar) and warning system.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>the main conclusion to be drawn is that</b> used when you want to mention the main point that you think is true because of what has been written earlier in the article or essay:
<ul>
	<li><b>The main conclusion to be drawn</b> from this discussion <b>is that</b> the best way to help slow readers is to improve their skill at recognizing individual words.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<p align="left"><b><i>2. Saying again what your aims were at the conclusion of an essay </i></b></p>
<p align="left"><b>STUDY NOTE: Grammar </b></p>
When you are writing the concluding paragraph of an essay, report etc, you often begin by saying what you wanted to achieve when you were writing the essay. The following are some phrases you can use.
<p align="left"></p>
<b>the purpose / aim of this ... was to ... </b>used at the end of an essay, article, report, etc, when saying what its purpose was and whether you have succeeded, what you have found, etc:
<ul>
	<li><b>The aim of this study was to</b><i> </i>determine whether it is possible to reduce the amount of salt in bread without spoiling its taste.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>in this ... I have tried / attempted to ... </b>used at the end of an essay, article, report, etc, when saying what its purpose was and whether you have succeeded, what you have found, etc:
<ul>
	<li><b>In this essay</b>, <b>I have tried to</b> set out the main events that led to the start of the First World War.</li>
	<li><b>In this report, we have attempted to</b> demonstrate that although nuclear power is cleaner than using gas or coal, it is more expensive in the long-term.</li>
</ul>
<h1>Decreasing</h1>
<h2>Decreasing</h2>
*opposite <b>Increasing</b>
<p align="left"></p>

<ol>
	<li>To decrease</li>
	<li>To make something decrease</li>
	<li>A decrease</li>
	<li>When something stops decreasing</li>
</ol>
<p align="left"></p>
<p align="left"><b><i>1. To decrease </i></b></p>
<b>decrease </b><i>verb</i> [intransitive] to become less in number or amount:
<ul>
	<li>The average rainfall has <b>decreased by</b> around 30 percent.</li>
	<li>The total number of people who are unemployed has <b>decreased slightly.</b></li>
	<li>After radiotherapy, the number of tumours <b>decreased significantly.</b></li>
	<li>The effectiveness of the drug <b>gradually decreases.</b></li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>go down </b><i>phrasal verb</i> to decrease:
<ul>
	<li>The percentage of fat in our diets has <b>gone down</b>.</li>
	<li>As a result of the improvements, complaints from customers <b>went down by </b>more than 70%.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<p align="left"><b>STUDY NOTE: Grammar </b></p>
<b>Decrease</b> is more formal than <b>go down.</b>

If you want to say that something 'has decreased', you can say that it<b> is down</b>, for example: <i>Inflation </i><b><i>is down</i></b><i> to 4%.</i>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>decline </b><i>verb</i> [intransitive] a formal word meaning to decrease. <b>Decline</b> is used about numbers or amounts, and also about the level or standard of something:
<ul>
	<li>In rural areas, the standard of living continued to <b>decline</b>.</li>
	<li>Salaries have effectively <b>declined by</b> around 4.5%.</li>
	<li>The rate of inflation has <b>declined sharply</b> in the past year. (=quickly and by a large amount)</li>
	<li>Support for the government is <b>steadily declining</b>.</li>
	<li>The city has <b>declined in importance.</b></li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>fall / drop </b><i>verb</i> [intransitive] to decrease, especially by a large amount:
<ul>
	<li>The number of tigers in the wild has <b>fallen to</b> just over 10,000.</li>
	<li>At night, the temperature <b>drops to</b> minus 20 degrees.</li>
	<li>Profits <b>fell from</b> £98.5 million <b>to</b> £76 million.</li>
	<li>In May, the price of coffee <b>dropped by</b> over 20%..</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>plunge / plummet </b><i>verb</i> [intransitive] to suddenly decrease very quickly and by a very large amount:
<ul>
	<li>Gas prices have <b>plunged</b> 31 percent in less than a week.</li>
	<li>Sales of red meat are <b>plummeting</b>.</li>
	<li>Climate change could cause global temperatures to <b>plummet</b>.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>halve</b> <i>verb</i> [intransitive] to decrease by a half:
<ul>
	<li>He expects the number of farms to <b>halve</b> by 2020.</li>
	<li>In 1965, 49% of Canadians smoked. This figure has more than <b>halved</b>.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"><b> </b></p>
<b>diminish </b><i>verb</i> [intransitive] to decrease to a low number, amount, or level. Diminish is used about numbers or amounts. It is also used when saying that a feeling becomes less strong, or that something becomes less important:
<ul>
	<li>The numbers of fish have <b>diminished</b> over the years.</li>
	<li>The population of the town <b>diminished from</b> 32,000 <b>to</b> 9,000 between 1871 and 1913.</li>
	<li>The pain gradually <b>diminished</b>.</li>
	<li>Although Campbell's influence <b>had diminished</b>, he continued to speak out against the war.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>dwindle</b> <i>verb</i> [intransitive] to gradually decrease until there is very little left of something. <b>Dwindle</b> is used about numbers or amounts. It is also used when saying that something becomes less popular, less important etc:
<ul>
	<li>The birds' numbers have slowly <b>dwindled</b>, until there are now only about 600 left in the world.</li>
	<li>Traffic along the canals <b>dwindled</b> during the 20th century.</li>
	<li>Support for the theory is <b>dwindling</b>.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<p align="left"><b><i>2. To make something decrease </i></b></p>
<b>reduce </b><i>verb</i> [transitive] to make something smaller in size, number or amount:
<ul>
	<li>The army was <b>greatly reduced in</b> size.</li>
	<li>The number of serious accidents has been <b>reduced by</b> a quarter.</li>
	<li>Doctors are urging people to <b>reduce</b> the amount of salt in their diet.</li>
	<li>Using new technology will help to <b>reduce</b> costs.</li>
	<li>Washing your hands helps to <b>reduce the risk</b> of infection.</li>
	<li>The ability to communicate cheaply over long distances has <b>reduced the need for</b> workers to commute to offices.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>lower </b><i>verb</i> [transitive] to reduce the amount or level of something:
<ul>
	<li>It is a basic rule in economics that if you want people to buy more of your products, you <b>lower</b> the price.</li>
	<li>The voting age <b>was lowered</b> to 18.</li>
	<li>They decided to lower interest rates by a quarter of a percent.</li>
	<li>The drug is used to <b>lower</b> blood pressure.</li>
	<li>Some colleges have had to <b>lower</b> their standards.</li>
	<li>To cool, the motor forces air out of the box, so <b>lowering</b> the temperature.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<p align="left"><b>STUDY NOTE: Grammar </b></p>
<b>Lower</b> is used especially in more formal contexts, for example when writing about politics, business, or technical matters. <b>Bring down</b> is less formal.
<p align="left"></p>
<b>bring down </b><i>phrasal verb</i> to reduce something such as prices or costs, or reduce the level of something:
<ul>
	<li>They used cheaper materials in an effort to <b>bring down</b> costs.</li>
	<li>The wage freeze was part of a campaign to <b>bring down</b> inflation.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>cut</b> <i>verb</i> [transitive] to reduce something such as prices, costs, time, or money, usually by a large amount:
<ul>
	<li>Companies are constantly looking for ways to <b>cut</b> their costs.</li>
	<li>Shell is to <b>cut</b> the price of petrol by 18p a gallon from midnight tomorrow.</li>
	<li>The new service will <b>cut</b> the journey time from London to Manchester <b>to</b> just over 2 hours.</li>
	<li>The working week has been <b>cut from</b> 39 hours <b>to</b> 35.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>halve</b> <i>verb</i> [transitive] to reduce something by a half:
<ul>
	<li>Costs were <b>halved</b>.</li>
	<li>The new drugs have <b>halved</b> the number of deaths among AIDS patients.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>relieve / ease </b><i>verb</i> [transitive] to make pain or feelings less unpleasant:
<ul>
	<li>Doctors are allowed to give drugs to <b>relieve pain</b>, even if they shorten life.</li>
	<li>Accordingly, they hired more telephone representatives <b>to relieve the pressure on</b> employees who handle customer complaints and inquiries.</li>
	<li>Making a joke can help to <b>relieve the tension.</b></li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>alleviate</b> <i>verb</i> [transitive] a formal word meaning to reduce pain or suffering, or make a problem less serious:
<ul>
	<li>Gentle regular exercise helps to <b>alleviate the problem.</b></li>
	<li>Changes in diet can help to <b>alleviate the symptoms</b> of the disease.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<p align="left"><b><i>3. A decrease </i></b></p>
<b>decrease</b> <i>noun</i> [uncountable and countable] used when something happens less than it used to:
<ul>
	<li>There has a been a <b>significant decrease in</b> the number of deaths from lung cancer.</li>
	<li>In August there was a <b>slight decrease</b> in the rate of unemployment.</li>
	<li>Latest figures show an <b>overall</b> 27% <b>decrease</b> in crime in the area since the project began.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>reduction</b> <i>noun</i> [uncountable and countable] used when the price, amount, or level of something is made lower:
<ul>
	<li>A small <b>reduction</b> in costs can mean a large increase in profits.</li>
	<li>There has been a <b>significant reduction</b> <b>in</b> traffic.</li>
	<li>Over the last few years there has been a <b>dramatic reduction in</b> (=surprisingly large) the number of people arrested for drink-driving.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>cut</b> <i>noun</i> [countable] used when a government or company reduces the price, amount, or level of something:
<ul>
	<li><b>price cuts </b></li>
	<li><b>tax cuts </b></li>
	<li><b>pay cuts </b></li>
	<li>The company is planning further <b>job cuts.</b></li>
	<li>There have been major <b>cuts in</b> government spending on defence.</li>
	<li>The state of California introduced new laws requiring <b>drastic cuts in</b> (=very big cuts) air pollution from automobiles.</li>
	<li>The bank announced a 1 per cent <b>cut in</b> interest rates.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>drop / fall</b> <i>noun</i> [countable] used when a number or amount goes down, especially by a large amount:
<ul>
	<li>The company reported a 35% <b>drop in</b> profits.</li>
	<li>Researchers found that the number of trees had gone down from 506 to 261, <b>a drop of</b> 48 percent.</li>
	<li>Spain has suffered a <b>sharp fall in</b> its birth rate. (=a sudden very large fall)</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>decline</b> <i>noun</i> [singular,uncountable] a formal word, used when the number, amount, level, or standard of something goes down:
<ul>
	<li>There has been a <b>gradual decline in</b> the number of homeless people.</li>
	<li>Television is often blamed for the <b>decline in</b> moral standards in our society.</li>
	<li>There has been a <b>slight decline in</b> the level of violence.</li>
	<li>Four years ago, there were 580 people living on the island, but there are now only 337. That is a <b>decline of</b> 42 percent.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<p align="left"><b><i>4. When something stops decreasing </i></b></p>
<b>level off / out</b> <i>phrasal verb</i> to stop decreasing and remain at the same level:
<ul>
	<li>The population dropped from a peak of 800,000, <b>levelling off</b> in 1999 at 650,000.</li>
	<li>Latest figures suggest inflation will <b>level out</b> at 2.4% after a year at over 3%.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>bottom out</b> <i>phrasal verb</i> to reach the lowest point, and stop decreasing any more:
<ul>
	<li>The decline in car sales finally showed signs of <b>bottoming out</b> in September.</li>
	<li>There is no evidence that the recession has <b>bottomed out</b> yet.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>

<h1>Disagreeing</h1>
<h2>Disagreeing</h2>
*opposite <b>Agreeing</b>
<p align="left"></p>

<ol>
	<li>To disagree with someone or with an opinion</li>
	<li>When people disagree about something</li>
	<li>Causing disagreement</li>
</ol>
<p align="left"></p>
<p align="left"><b><i>1. To disagree with someone or with an opinion </i></b></p>

<h3>disagree / not agree <i>verb</i> [intransitive]:</h3>
<ul>
	<li>Scholars continue to <b>disagree about</b> the meaning behind the poem.</li>
	<li>Although he <b>did not agree with</b> Plato, he was profoundly influenced by him.</li>
	<li>Scientists <b>disagree among themselves on</b> what causes the disease.</li>
	<li>I <b>strongly disagree with</b> his views on immigration. (=I disagree with them very much)</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>take issue with</b> a formal phrase meaning to strongly disagree with what someone has said:
<ul>
	<li>I feel that I must <b>take issue with</b> the article's conclusion.</li>
	<li>Some people have <b>taken issue with</b> Conrad's description of the Congo in his novel 'The Heart of Darkness'.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>dispute</b> <i>verb</i> [transitive] to say that you think that something is not correct or not true:
<ul>
	<li>Researchers have <b>disputed</b> her <b>claims</b>.</li>
	<li>No one <b>disputes that</b> the problem exists.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>differ</b> <i>verb</i> [intransitive] if people <b>differ</b> about something, they have a range of different opinions about it. If <b>opinions, views</b>, or <b>tastes differ</b>, people have different opinions, views, or tastes:
<ul>
	<li>Critics <b>differed sharply on</b> the merits of his work. (=they had very different opinions)</li>
	<li><b>Opinions differ</b> about the proper relationship between the mass media and society.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>be divided / split</b> <i>adjective</i> if a group of people is <b>divided</b> or <b>split</b> on something, some of them have one opinion and others have a completely different opinion:
<ul>
	<li>America's doctors remain <b>deeply divided on</b> the issue of whether it should be legal for a physician to help a terminally ill patient commit suicide.</li>
	<li>Scientists <b>were split on</b> the uses to which the discoveries of atomic physics were being put.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>be mistaken</b> <i>adjective</i> used to say that you disagree with someone or with an opinion that they have, and think that they are wrong:
<ul>
	<li>He <b>is mistaken</b> if he believes that the United States will not respond to this threat.</li>
	<li>Such a view <b>is</b>, however, <b>seriously mistaken. </b></li>
</ul>
<p align="left"><b> </b></p>
<p align="left"><b><i>2. When people disagree about something </i></b></p>
<b>disagreement</b> <i>noun</i> [uncountable and countable] if there is <b>disagreement</b> about something, people do not agree about it:
<ul>
	<li>There is considerable <b>disagreement among</b> experts <b>about</b> the usefulness of these tests.</li>
	<li>She found herself <b>in disagreement with</b> her colleagues <b>on</b> the issue. (=she found that she disagreed with them about it)</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>dispute</b> <i>noun</i> [uncountable and countable] a serious disagreement, in which two people, organizations, or countries publicly disagree and argue with each other:
<ul>
	<li>He became involved in a long legal <b>dispute with</b> his publisher.</li>
	<li>There is considerable <b>dispute over</b> the precise definition of this term.</li>
	<li>The United Nations is trying to settle the bitter and long-running <b>dispute between</b> the two countries.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>controversy</b> <i>noun</i> [uncountable and countable] serious disagreement, especially with people expressing strongly opposing views in newspapers, in books, on television etc:
<ul>
	<li>There has been a lot of <b>controversy over</b> abortion in the US.</li>
	<li>Alice Walker writes about the <b>controversy surrounding</b> the film version of her novel, 'The Color Purple'.</li>
	<li>There is some <b>controversy</b> <b>among</b> biologists <b>about</b> whether this is actually true.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<p align="left"><b><i>3. Causing disagreement </i></b></p>
<b>contentious</b> <i>adjective</i> a formal word used to describe statements and situations that cause a lot of disagreement and argument:
<ul>
	<li>Water has been a <b>contentious issue</b> between Turkey and its neighbours for years.</li>
	<li>One particularly <b>contentious area</b> in the field of health and safety is the valuation of human life itself.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>controversial</b> <i>adjective</i> causing a lot of disagreement among people, with strongly opposing opinions being expressed in newspapers, in books, on television etc:
<ul>
	<li>The use of genetic tests is a <b>controversial issue.</b></li>
	<li>The judge's decision was <b>highly controversial</b> at the time.</li>
	<li>Oliver Cromwell remains a somewhat <b>controversial</b> historical <b>figure</b>.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>divisive</b> <i>adjective</i> causing arguments between people and making them form into two opposing groups:
<ul>
	<li>The war was extremely <b>divisive</b>.</li>
	<li>Same-sex marriage remains a <b>divisive</b> issue in many parts of the US.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>

<h1>Effects</h1>
<h2>Effects</h2>
*see also <b>Causes</b>
<p align="left"></p>

<ol>
	<li>Words meaning effect</li>
	<li>To affect something or someone</li>
</ol>
<p align="left"></p>
<p align="left"><b><i>1. Words meaning effect </i></b></p>
<b>effect </b><i>noun</i> [uncountable and countable] a change caused by something:
<ul>
	<li>She was one of the first scientists to study the <b>effects of</b> radiation <b>on</b> the human body.</li>
	<li>At first, the treatment seemed to <b>have</b> no <b>effect</b>.</li>
	<li>Some people believe that television has a <b>positive effect</b> on our lives, while others think that it has a <b>negative effect.</b></li>
	<li>Building hundreds of new homes is likely to have an <b>adverse effect on</b> the environment. (=a bad effect)</li>
	<li>The food we eat has a <b>significant effect upon</b> our mental ability. (=an important and noticeable effect)</li>
	<li>The decision could have <b>far-reaching effects</b>. (=on a lot of things or people)</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<p align="left"><b>STUDY NOTE: Grammar </b></p>
Don't forget that <b>effect</b> is a noun and <b>affect</b> is a verb.
<p align="left"></p>
<b>impact </b><i>noun</i> [uncountable and countable] the effect that something has, especially a big and permanent effect that happens as a result of something important:
<ul>
	<li>In practice, the change in the law did not <b>have</b> much <b>impact</b>.</li>
	<li>His work has had an <b>enormous</b> <b>impact</b> <b>on</b> the study of genetics. (=a very big impact) • The war had a <b>devastating impact on</b> the country's industries. (=it caused a great amount of damage)</li>
	<li>Population growth will have a <b>profound impact upon</b> world demand for food. (=a very big impact)</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>influence </b><i>noun</i> [uncountable and countable] the effect that something has on people's opinions or behaviour, or on how something develops:
<ul>
	<li>In his book, McCluhan examines the <b>influence of</b> the media on our society.</li>
	<li>The English philosopher Thomas Hobbes <b>had a considerable influence on </b>Spinoza.</li>
	<li>For much of the 20th century, Berlin <b>exerted</b> a unique <b>influence on</b> the world. (=it had a unique influence)</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<p align="left"></p>
<p align="left"></p>
<p align="left"><b>STUDY NOTE: Grammar </b></p>
The usual preposition to use with <b>effect</b>, <b>impact</b>, or <b>influence</b> is <b>on</b>. In formal English, people also use upon with the same meaning.
<p align="left"></p>
<b>side effect </b><i>noun</i> [countable] an unwanted effect that something has in addition to its good effects. <b>Side effect</b> is used especially about drugs and medical treatment:
<ul>
	<li>Experts warn that this is a powerful drug which can have dangerous <b>side effects</b>.</li>
	<li>Common <b>side effects</b> of the treatment include headaches and muscle pains.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>aftereffects </b><i>noun</i> [plural] bad effects that continue for a long time after the thing that caused them:
<ul>
	<li>The country is still suffering from the <b>aftereffects</b> of war.</li>
	<li>The <b>aftereffects</b> of the illness can last for months.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>knock-on effect</b> <i>noun</i> [uncountable and countable] a British English phrase, used when something has an effect on something, which then has an effect on something else:
<ul>
	<li>The strikes are likely to have a <b>knock-on effect</b> <b>on</b> the whole economy.</li>
	<li>If one flight is delayed, it can have <b>knock-on effects on </b>the other flights.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>repercussions</b> <i>noun</i> [plural] the bad effects that happen later as a result of an event, which continue for a long time afterwards:
<ul>
	<li>It was a major economic crisis with serious social and political <b>repercussions</b>.</li>
	<li>The scandal could have serious <b>repercussions</b> <b>for</b> her political career.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>implications</b> <i>noun</i> [plural] the possible effects that something is likely to have in the future:
<ul>
	<li>The results of the study could have <b>important implications for</b> future educational policy.</li>
	<li>Some people believe that the increase in air travel will have serious<b> implications for</b> the climate.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<p align="left"><b><i>2. To affect something or someone </i></b></p>
<b>affect </b><i>verb</i> [transitive] to have an effect on something or someone:
<ul>
	<li>The disease <b>affects</b> women more than men.</li>
	<li>The island was <b>badly affected</b> by last month's storms.</li>
	<li>Smoking while you are pregnant can <b>seriously affect</b> the health of your unborn baby.</li>
	<li>Noise from the airport is <b>adversely affecting</b> the quality of life for local residents. (=it is having a bad effect on their lives)</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>be bad for </b>to have a bad effect on someone or something:
<ul>
	<li>When companies close down it <b>is bad for</b> the local economy.</li>
	<li>Studies have shown that eating some types of fish can <b>be bad for</b> you.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>be good for </b>to have a good effect on someone or something:
<ul>
	<li>Mr Blair's speech contained analysis of how environmental action can <b>be good for</b> the economy and for business.</li>
	<li>Bread, especially brown bread, <b>is good for</b> you.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>Impact / impact on </b><i>verb</i> [intransitive and transitive] to affect something. <b>Impact</b> is used as a verb especially in business English:
<ul>
	<li>The recession in the US has <b>negatively impacted</b> sales of luxury cars. (=it has had a bad effect on sales)</li>
	<li>The new regulations will <b>significantly impact</b> <b>on</b> the way food companies operate. (=they will have an important and noticeable effect)</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>make a difference </b>to have a noticeable effect on a situation:
<ul>
	<li>New drugs have <b>made a big difference</b> in the treatment of some forms of cancer.</li>
	<li>In practice <b>it makes very little difference</b> which type of oil you use.</li>
	<li>Choosing the right wine <b>can make all the difference</b> to a meal. (=the right choice will make it a very enjoyable meal)</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>influence</b> <i>verb</i> [transitive] to have an effect on the way someone behaves or thinks, or on the way a situation develops:
<ul>
	<li>There is no convincing evidence that advertising <b>influences</b> total sales of alcohol.</li>
	<li>Morgan was <b>heavily influenced</b> by Darwin's ideas on evolution. (=he was greatly influenced by them)</li>
	<li>Levels of ozone are <b>strongly influenced</b> by annual variations in the weather.</li>
</ul>
<h1>Emphasizing</h1>
<h2>Emphasizing</h2>
<ol>
	<li>What you say when emphasizing that something is important</li>
	<li>Ways of emphasizing one person or thing more than others</li>
	<li>To emphasize something</li>
</ol>
<p align="left"></p>
<p align="left"><b><i>1. What you say when emphasizing that something is important </i></b></p>
<b>I would like to stress that</b> used when you want to emphasize that something is important:
<ul>
	<li><b>I would like to stress that</b> the research is still at an early stage.</li>
	<li><b>I would like to stress that</b> the characters in this poem bear no resemblance to real people.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>it should be noted that</b> a formal phrase used especially in articles and essays, when you want to emphasize that something is important:
<ul>
	<li><b>It should be noted that</b> there are a number of alternative methods available.</li>
	<li><b>It should be noted that</b> the general trend of increasing unemployment has continued over a number of years.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>it is worth bearing in mind that</b> used when you want to emphasize that it is important to remember something when you are considering a subject:
<ul>
	<li><b>It is worth bearing in mind that</b> 90% of the scientists researching herbicides in the US are employed by chemical companies.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>crucial</b> <i>adjective</i> if something is <b>crucial</b>, it is extremely important:
<ul>
	<li>Burgin distinguishes between photographic theory and photographic criticism (Burgin 1982). This distinction is <b>crucial</b>.</li>
	<li>Factors such as temperature and acidity <b>play a crucial role</b> in determining how well the process works.</li>
</ul>
<b>crucially</b> <b>Crucially</b>, it was claimed that there was an increase in childhood cancers in areas surrounding nuclear power stations.
<p align="left"></p>
<b>vital / essential</b> <i>adjective</i> if something is <b>vital</b> or <b>essential</b>, it is extremely important, because without it there could be serious problems:
<ul>
	<li>These insects play a <b>vital</b> part in the food chain.</li>
	<li><b>It is essential that</b> the work is carried out as soon as possible.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<p align="left"><b><i>2. Ways of emphasizing one person or thing more than others </i></b><b>especially / particularly</b> adverb:</p>

<ul>
	<li>The climate is much colder, <b>especially</b> in the far north.</li>
	<li>There has been a big increase in alcohol consumption, <b>particularly</b> among young women.</li>
	<li>It is often mixed with other fibres, <b>particularly</b> cotton.</li>
	<li>He was very much influenced by Picasso, <b>especially</b> when he was young.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<p align="left"><b>STUDY NOTE: Grammar </b></p>
<b>Especially</b> and <b>particularly</b> are usually used before a noun phrase or at the beginning of a clause.
<p align="left"></p>
<b>in particular</b> used when you want to mention one person or thing that is more important than others or more affected by something than others:
<ul>
	<li>In the USA <b>in particular</b>, large numbers of ordinary citizens lost money by investing in internet companies.</li>
	<li>The work of Sally Mann, <b>in particular</b>, has made us question representations of children and childhood.</li>
	<li>One of the biggest environmental issues was the movement of hazardous waste. <b>In particular,</b> there was concern about rich, industrialized countries exporting such waste to poor developing countries.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"><b>STUDY NOTE: Grammar </b></p>
<b>In particular</b> is usually used after a noun phrase. It can also be used at the beginning of a sentence.
<p align="left"></p>
<b>notably</b> <i>adverb</i> used when saying that someone or something is an important example of something. <b>Notably</b> is a formal word, which is used especially in articles and essays:
<ul>
	<li>Some economists, most <b>notably</b> J. M. Keynes, recommended increasing government spending in times of recession, in order to stimulate the economy.</li>
	<li>In 1950, half the world's ships were built in the UK (<b>notably</b> in Liverpool, Sunderland, Belfast and Glasgow).</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>above all</b> used when emphasizing that something is more important than the other things you have mentioned:
<ul>
	<li>Cycling is not only pollution-free but also flexible, cheap, and <b>above all</b>, healthy.</li>
	<li>Try to find out if your daughter has any other worries or problems. <b>Above all</b>, show her that you care and will give her all the support and help you can.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>most of all </b>more than anyone or anything else:<b> </b>
<ul>
	<li>America had become an importer of copper, lead, zinc, and <b>most of all</b>, oil.</li>
	<li><b>Most of all</b>, we need an approach that works.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>

<h3>most importantly / most significantly:</h3>
<ul>
	<li>Perhaps <b>most importantly</b>, the nation seemed to have lost its pride and its sense of direction.</li>
	<li>The 18th century was a period of enormous social change. <b>Most significantly</b>, the Agricultural Revolution drove large numbers of workers into the cities.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<p align="left"><b><i>3. To emphasize something </i></b></p>
<b>emphasize / stress</b> <i>verb</i> [transitive] to say firmly that something is particularly important:
<ul>
	<li>In their report, they <b>emphasized</b> the need for better police training.</li>
	<li>She <b>stresses that</b> death is not always the aim of those who try to commit suicide.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>highlight</b> <i>verb</i> [transitive] to show that something such as a problem or fact is particularly important, especially by providing new information about it:
<ul>
	<li>This case <b>highlights</b> some of the problems associated with patients travelling long distances for treatment.</li>
	<li>Campbell is more concerned with <b>highlighting</b> the issues involved, rather than providing solutions.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>underline / underscore</b> <i>verb</i> [transitive] to show clearly that something is true:
<ul>
	<li>The high rate of mortality <b>underlines</b> the need for a greater understanding of the causes of the disease.</li>
	<li>Studies and statistics <b>underscore</b> the fact that much of the country's wealth is in the hands of a tiny minority.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>draw attention to</b> to say that something is important and needs to be considered, or to make people realise that something is important:
<ul>
	<li>A number of writers have <b>drawn attention to</b> this fact.</li>
	<li>The study was one of the first to <b>draw attention to</b> the problems faced by severely disabled adults.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>point up</b> <i>phrasal verb</i> to write about something in a way that shows it is very important:
<ul>
	<li>The report <b>pointed up</b> the need for more research on the subject.</li>
</ul>
<h1>Explaining</h1>
<h2>Explaining</h2>
<ol>
	<li>What you say when you are explaining something</li>
	<li>Words meaning to explain something</li>
</ol>
<p align="left"></p>
<p align="left"><b><i>1. What you say when you are explaining something </i></b></p>
<b>this means that / which means that </b>used when saying what the results or effects of what you have just said are:
<ul>
	<li>Computer technology is constantly being improved. <b>This means that</b> the computer that you have just bought will probably be out of date in only a few months' time.</li>
	<li>There is a shortage of hospital doctors, <b>which means that</b> patients often have to wait a long time for treatment.</li>
	<li>The bank's current interest rate is 3.5%. <b>This means that</b> for every £100 you have in your savings account, you will get £3.50 in interest.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<p align="left"><b>STUDY NOTE: Grammar </b></p>
You use <b>This means that</b> at the beginning of a sentence. You use <b>which means that</b> at the beginning of a clause.
<p align="left"></p>
<b>that is </b>used when explaining the meaning of the previous word or phrase, by giving more information:
<ul>
	<li>The book is about art in the modern period, <b>that is</b>, art since 1900.</li>
	<li>Her son suffers from Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder. <b>That is</b>, he finds it difficult to pay attention or stay quiet for more than a short period of time.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>Ie /i.e. </b>used when explaining the meaning of the previous word or phrase, by giving more information:
<ul>
	<li>The new law will come into force at the end of next month,<b> ie</b> March 31st.</li>
	<li>There has been a decline in the number of 'good' jobs, <b>i.e.</b> ones that are highly skilled and well-paid.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<p align="left"><b>STUDY NOTE: Grammar </b></p>
<b>ie</b> is the abbreviation for <b>id est</b>, which is Latin for <b>that is.</b> In formal essay writing, it is usually better to use <b>that is</b>.
<p align="left"></p>
<b>in other words / to put it another way </b>used when saying something in a different way, either in order to explain it more clearly, or to emphasize the point that you want to make:
<ul>
	<li>Average incomes fell, while the incomes of the top 20 percent of the population increased. <b>In other words</b>, the rich got richer.</li>
	<li>In a democracy, the government must be accountable to the people. The people should, <b>in other words</b>, be able to get rid of their rulers through elections.</li>
	<li>Using this software would offer a 15% saving in space. <b>To put it another way</b>, this will mean an extra 12Gb free on an 80Gb disk.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>to put it simply </b>used when saying something in a simple way so that the reader can understand what you mean:
<ul>
	<li>What the treatment aims to do, <b>to put it simply</b>, is to make the skin grow back over the wound.</li>
	<li>A romantic novel should demand a certain level of emotional involvement on the part of the reader. <b>To put it simply</b>, the novel should not just describe a love relationship; it should allow the reader to participate in it.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>specifically</b> <i>adverb</i> used when saying exactly what you are referring to, when you are explaining something:
<ul>
	<li>Several prisoners reported some kind of physical abuse. <b>Specifically</b>, 42 were beaten; eight were roughly handled; and four more were forced to remain standing for hours at a time.</li>
	<li>What we need is a stable economic climate that encourages companies to invest on a long-term basis. <b>More specifically</b>, we need to get rid of the current high taxes on investment income.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<p align="left"><b><i>2. Words meaning to explain something </i></b></p>
<b>explain </b><i>verb </i>[intransitive and transitive] to give someone the information that they need in order to understand something:
<ul>
	<li>He was the first scientist to <b>explain how</b> the process of evolution works.</li>
	<li>The book begins by <b>explaining</b> the difference between psychology and psychiatry.</li>
	<li>There are a number of theories which seek to <b>explain why</b> (=try to explain why) zebras have stripes.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>

<h3>give / offer / provide an explanation to explain something:</h3>
<ul>
	<li>He attempts to <b>give</b> a simple <b>explanation</b> of his theory.</li>
	<li>It is possible that some recent research by NASA scientists could <b>offer</b> <b>an</b> <b>explanation</b> for this phenomenon.</li>
	<li>They were unable to <b>provide</b> a satisfactory <b>explanation</b> for their behaviour.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>set out </b><i>phrasal verb </i>to explain facts, reasons, plans etc by stating them clearly and in a carefully planned order:
<ul>
	<li>He <b>sets out </b>his plans for an ideal Roman city in the first volume of his work.</li>
	<li>The document <b>sets out</b> exactly <b>how</b> the money will be spent.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>go through </b><i>phrasal verb </i>to explain all the details about something in the right order, so that someone can understand it:
<ul>
	<li>She begins her article by <b>going through</b> all the reasons why people have opposed the use of nuclear energy.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>outline</b> <i>verb </i>[transitive] to explain the main ideas about something, without giving all the details:
<ul>
	<li>In his introduction, Piaget <b>outlines</b> the four main stages in a child's development.</li>
	<li>The purpose of this chapter is to <b>outline</b> the basic principles which form the foundations of the English legal system.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>expand on </b><i>phrasal verb </i>to add more details or information to what has already been said:
<ul>
	<li>Melville saw the ocean as the source of all life. He <b>expands on</b> this idea in his novel, 'Moby Dick'.</li>
	<li>The author <b>expands on</b> this theme <b>at length</b> (=writes a lot about it).</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>clarify</b> <i>verb </i>[transitive] to make something clearer:
<ul>
	<li>This chapter aims to <b>clarify</b> some of the most important issues in genetics today.</li>
	<li>In his speech the prime minister attempted to <b>clarify</b> his position on economic reform.</li>
</ul>
<h1>Giving Example</h1>
<h2>Giving Example</h2>
<ol>
	<li>What you say when giving an example</li>
	<li>What you say when there are a lot of other examples of something</li>
	<li>To give something or someone as an example</li>
</ol>
<p align="left"></p>
<p align="left"><b><i>1. What you say when giving an example </i></b></p>
<b>for example</b> used when giving an example of the kind of thing that you have just mentioned:
<ul>
	<li>People watch huge amounts of television. In the United States, <b>for example</b>, many children spend more hours watching television than they do attending school.</li>
	<li>A lot of English words come from Latin. <b>For example</b> 'homicide' comes from the Latin words 'homo' (=man) and 'cidium' (=killing).</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<p align="left"><b>STUDY NOTE: Grammar </b></p>
<p align="left">In essays, <b>for example</b> is often used later on in a sentence, rather than at the beginning: The influence of Eastern music can be heard in Western classical music, <b>for example</b> in the piano works of Debussy.</p>
The abbreviation of <b>for example</b> is <b>eg</b>. In formal essays you usually use the full phrase <b>for example.</b>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>for instance</b> means the same as <b>for example</b>, but it is slightly less formal:
<ul>
	<li>Our climate is already showing signs of change. Last year<b>, for instance</b>, was one of the hottest summers on record.</li>
	<li>There is a great deal we can do to reduce the amount of pollution we produce.<b> For instance,</b> we can use our cars less, and use public transport instead.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>particularly / in particular</b> <i>adverb</i> used when saying that something is especially true about someone or something:
<ul>
	<li>Tourism is very important for the economy, <b>particularly</b> in the south of the country.</li>
	<li>His work had a big influence on Picasso <b>in particular</b>.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>

<h3>be a good / typical / classic / obvious etc example:</h3>
<ul>
	<li>The United Kingdom is a <b>good example</b> of a country that consists of several smaller states.</li>
	<li>Her case is a <b>classic example</b> of this kind of problem.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>be a case in point</b> used when saying that something is a very good and relevant example of the kind of thing that you have just mentioned:
<ul>
	<li>Many native English plants and animals are under threat. The red squirrel is a <b>case in point</b>.</li>
	<li>The government has consistently ignored basic human rights. <b>A case in point</b> is the recent killing of 10 political prisoners.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>take / consider</b> <i>verb</i> [transitive] used when you are about to talk about a particular situation that you want to show as an example:
<ul>
	<li>Science has yet to answer some important questions. <b>Take, for instance</b>, (=consider the following example) the theory that the universe started with the 'big bang'. What came before the big bang?</li>
	<li>Many students are bored with their studies. <b>Consider</b> the case of Christina. She is a hard-working student who plans to go to college. Yet she says of her education, "It's not like I'm thinking a lot here."</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<p align="left"><b>STUDY NOTE: Grammar </b></p>
<b>Take</b> and <b>consider</b> are always used at the start of a sentence.
<p align="left"></p>
<b>by way of illustration</b> <i>a formal phrase</i>, used especially when you are going to give a long example that shows what you mean:
<ul>
	<li>Revolutions often lead to dictatorships. <b>By way of illustration</b>, consider the events that followed the French Revolution.</li>
	<li>Plants have been used in Cambodia in many ways for many centuries. <b>By way of illustration</b>, of the 2,300 species of plants in Cambodia, approximately 40 percent have a traditional use, primarily as food and medicine.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>be shown by</b> used when giving an example which shows that what you are saying is true:
<ul>
	<li>The people who live there are quite rich. <b>This is shown by</b> the size of their houses.</li>
	<li>Metal tools were produced here for thousands of years, <b>as is shown by</b> weapons discovered in ancient tombs.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>this is true of / this was true of</b> used when giving an example which shows that what you are saying is true:
<ul>
	<li>Many writers have suffered from discrimination. <b>This was true of</b> Oscar Wilde, and also of André Gide.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<p align="left"><b><i>2. What you say when there are a lot of other examples of something </i></b></p>
<b>such as</b> used when giving one or two typical examples of the kind of thing or person that you mean, when there are many other examples:
<ul>
	<li>The factory produced electrical goods <b>such as</b> washing machines and cookers.</li>
	<li>Girls do better than boys in subjects <b>such as</b> English.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<p align="left"><b>STUDY NOTE: Grammar </b></p>
<b>Such as</b> does not usually have a comma before it, whereas <b>for example</b> and <b>including</b> usually do.
<p align="left"></p>
<b>including</b> <i>preposition</i> used when you want to give examples of the kinds of thing that something includes:
<ul>
	<li>She has many interests, <b>including</b> opera and ballet.</li>
	<li>The company produces 340 drugs and cosmetic products, <b>including</b> penicillin, antibiotics and aspirins.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>to name but a few</b> used after examples of something, when saying that there are many more that you could mention:
<ul>
	<li>He wrote several famous books: '1984', 'Animal Farm', and 'The Road to Wigan Pier', <b>to name but a few</b>.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>etc / et cetera</b> <i>adverb</i> used when you want to say that there are many other examples of other things of the same kind:
<ul>
	<li>It is best to avoid tea, coffee, alcohol <b>etc</b>.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<p align="left"><b>STUDY NOTE: Grammar </b></p>
In formal essays it is better not to use <b>etc</b>, and to rephrase the sentence using <b>such as:</b> It is best to avoid drinks <b>such as</b> tea, coffee, or alcohol.

Do not use <b>eg</b> and <b>etc</b> in the same sentence.
<p align="left"></p>

<h3><i>3. To give something or someone as an example </i>give the example of something / give something as an example:</h3>
<ul>
	<li>The writer <b>gives the example of</b> Johnny Saxon who, three years after winning the world boxing title, was charged with burglary.</li>
	<li>He <b>gives as an example</b> the island of Aru in southeast Indonesia, where the number of turtles has decreased dramatically.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>cite</b> <i>verb</i> [transitive] a formal word meaning to give something or someone an example:
<ul>
	<li>She <b>cites</b> a survey last year, which showed that 84 percent of shoppers would be prepared to return containers to retailers if supermarkets set up a suitable system.</li>
	<li>Sendak <b>cites</b> Tolstoy as an example of an author who needs no illustrator.</li>
</ul>
<h1>Giving Exceptions</h1>
<h2>Giving Exceptions</h2>
<ol>
	<li>Ways of saying that something or someone is an exception</li>
	<li>Someone or something that is not included</li>
</ol>
<p align="left"></p>
<p align="left"><b><i>1. Ways of saying that something or someone is an exception </i></b></p>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>except</b> <i>preposition</i> used when saying that a statement does not include a particular person or thing:
<ul>
	<li>The office is open every day <b>except</b> Sundays.</li>
	<li>Most of the critics liked the play, <b>except for</b> one critic on the Los Angeles Times.</li>
	<li><b>Except for</b> a few years in the early sixties and seventies, inflation has been a continuing feature of American life since World War II.</li>
	<li>The area looks very much like the state of Iowa, <b>except that</b> it is surrounded by beautiful snow-covered mountains.</li>
	<li><b>Except in</b> an emergency, these doors must remain closed.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"><b> </b></p>
<p align="left"><b>STUDY NOTE: Grammar </b></p>
<b>Except</b> and <b>except for</b> mean the same thing. You can use except for and <b>except in</b> at the beginning of a sentence. Otherwise, <b>except</b> does not come at the beginning of a sentence.
<p align="left"></p>
<b>apart from / aside from</b> <i>preposition</i> used when mentioning one or two things that do not fit the main thing that you are saying, especially when they are not very important:
<ul>
	<li><b>Aside from</b> one or two minor errors, this is an excellent piece of research.</li>
	<li>The films were all made in Hollywood, <b>apart from</b> one, which was made in the UK.</li>
	<li>The weather was not very good in the first week. <b>Apart from that</b>, it was a good holiday.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>excluding / not including</b> <i>preposition</i> used when saying that something, especially a total number or amount, does not include a particular thing or person:
<ul>
	<li>The software costs $49.95, <b>not including</b> tax.</li>
	<li><b>Excluding</b> students, the total number of unemployed rose from 2 million to 2.3 million.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"><b> </b></p>
<p align="left"><b>STUDY NOTE: Grammar </b></p>
<p align="left"><b>Excluding</b> is more formal than <b>not including.</b></p>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>with the exception of / with one exception</b> formal phrases used when you want to emphasize that something does not include a particular thing or person:
<ul>
	<li>Denmark has more wind turbines than any other place in the world, <b>with the exception of </b>California.</li>
	<li><b>With the exception of</b> skin cancer, breast cancer is the most common cancer among women.</li>
	<li>The prisons are, <b>with one exception</b>, overcrowded and lacking in facilities for prisoners.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>but</b> <i>preposition</i> used especially after <b>nothing, no one, any, anyone, anything, all, everything</b> and <b>everyone</b>, when saying that something is the only thing, or someone is the only person:
<ul>
	<li>There is <b>nothing but</b> trees, for mile after mile. • The garment covers <b>everything but</b> the eyes.</li>
	<li><b>All but a few of</b> her family died of the disease.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>other than</b> a phrase meaning except, used especially in negative sentences:
<ul>
	<li>He had no interests <b>other than</b> teaching.</li>
	<li>No one <b>other than</b> her knew about the plan.</li>
	<li>Daley has said little about his childhood, <b>other than that</b> it was happy and normal.</li>
	<li>Some airlines will not allow you to take pets <b>other than</b> dogs, cats and birds.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>in a few cases / in a small number of cases</b> used when emphasizing that something only happens a few times or to a few people:
<ul>
	<li><b>In a few cases</b> the information has gone missing from the files.</li>
	<li>Surgery can only help <b>in a small number of cases. </b></li>
</ul>
<p align="left"><b> </b></p>
<p align="left"><b><i>2. Someone or something that is not included </i></b></p>
<b>exception</b> <i>noun</i> [uncountable and countable] someone or something that is different from the others and cannot therefore be included in a statement:
<ul>
	<li>The health of most of the patients improved, although there were one or two <b>exceptions</b>, (=one or two patients did not get better)</li>
	<li>Apart from a few <b>minor exceptions</b> (=unimportant exceptions), the two countries' legal systems are very similar.</li>
	<li>Not many first-rate writers have written about film. <b>A notable exception</b> (=an important exception) is Grahame Greene, who reviewed movies regularly between 1935 and 1940.</li>
	<li>All societies, <b>without exception</b>, share the same characteristics. (=used when saying that there are no exceptions)</li>
</ul>
<h1>Giving Opinions</h1>
<p align="left"></p>

<h2>Giving Opinions</h2>
<p align="left">*see also <b>Agreeing</b>,  <b>Disagreeing</b></p>
<p align="left"></p>

<ol>
	<li>What you say when giving your opinion about something</li>
	<li>Ways of saying what another person’s opinion is</li>
	<li>To say what your opinion is about something</li>
</ol>
<p align="left"></p>
<p align="left"><b><i>1. What you say when giving your opinion about something </i></b><b>in my opinion / in my view</b> used when giving your opinion about something:</p>

<ul>
	<li>Their concerns are, <b>in my opinion</b>, fully justified.</li>
	<li><b>In my opinion</b>, the cathedral is one of the world's most beautiful churches.</li>
	<li><b>In my view</b>, the court made the right decision.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<p align="left"><b>STUDY NOTE: Grammar </b></p>
Don't say 'According to my opinion' when you mean <b>in my opinion.</b>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>I think that</b> used when giving your opinion about something:
<ul>
	<li><b>I think that</b> everyone should be able to own their own home.</li>
	<li><b>I think that</b> hunting should be banned.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"><b>STUDY NOTE: Grammar </b></p>
In formal essay writing, people often try to avoid using phrases with ‘I’ or 'me', and use more impersonal phrases such as <b>in this writer’s view</b> or <b>in this writer's opinion. </b>
<p align="left"></p>
<p align="left">When you are writing essays, it is a good idea to quote another writer to support your argument, rather than just say <b>I think that</b> ... This will give your argument much more authority.</p>
For example: <i>As Hobsbawm (1969) has pointed out, the rise of the cotton industry created a huge demand for cotton goods. </i>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>in this writer’s view / opinion</b> used in formal essays when giving your opinion:
<ul>
	<li><b>In this writer's view</b>, the present system is in need of reform.</li>
	<li><b>In this writer's opinion</b>, the arguments against using nuclear energy are overwhelming.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>it seems to me that</b> used when saying that you think that something is probably true. You use this especially when you have considered a situation carefully and want to give your overall opinion about it:
<ul>
	<li><b>It seems to me that</b> there is some truth in her argument.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>I believe that</b> used about strongly held beliefs, for example about moral issues:

• <b>I believe that</b> the death penalty is morally wrong.
<p align="left"></p>
<p align="left"><b><i>2. Ways of saying what another person’s opinion is </i></b></p>
<b>somebody's opinion / view is that</b> used when saying what another writer's opinion is about something:
<ul>
	<li>The judge's <b>opinion was that</b> she was fit to stand trial.</li>
	<li><b>His view is that</b> consumers should be told the whole truth about the product they are buying.</li>
	<li><b>The general opinion is that</b> the combined vaccine works better. (=most people think this)</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>in somebody's opinion / view</b> used when saying what another writer's opinion is about something:
<ul>
	<li>The important thing, <b>in</b> Galileo's <b>opinion</b>, was to accept the facts and build a theory to fit them.</li>
	<li>Criticism is quite different, <b>in</b> Barthes's <b>view</b>, from ordinary reading.</li>
	<li><b>In his opinion</b>, the portrait painter seeks to capture the moment when the model looks most like himself or herself.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>be of the opinion that / take the view that</b> to have a particular opinion. These are formal phrases:
<ul>
	<li>Until then, most scientists <b>were of the opinion that</b> these variations in weather were compatible with established climate patterns.</li>
	<li>Levitt <b>takes the view that</b> low prices are the key to marketing success.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>have / hold an opinion</b> to have a particular opinion:
<ul>
	<li>Everybody <b>has</b> a different <b>opinion of</b> what America represents.</li>
	<li>They <b>held</b> the same <b>opinions on</b> many issues.</li>
	<li>Voters tend to <b>have a low opinion of</b> politicians. (=think they are not very good)</li>
	<li>Teenage girls generally <b>have a higher opinion of</b> themselves as learners than boys, according to a recent study. (=they think that they are better)</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>for somebody</b> <i>preposition</i> used when saying what someone's opinion is, especially when this is a general opinion which also affects their other ideas about a subject. <b>For somebody</b> is usually used at the beginning of a sentence:
<ul>
	<li><b>For</b> Chomsky, language is an abstract system of rules which is used by human minds for transmitting and receiving ideas.</li>
	<li><b>For Vygotsky</b>, social factors play a fundamental role in intellectual development.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>as far as somebody is concerned</b> used when you want to emphasize that you are talking about the opinion of a particular person or group:
<ul>
	<li><b>As far as</b> he <b>was concerned</b>, the failure showed the limits of military intervention.</li>
	<li>The election was a formality <b>as far as</b> the ruling party <b>was concerned</b>.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>from sb’s point of view</b> used when saying what someone's reaction to something is, based on how it affects them:
<ul>
	<li><b>From</b> their <b>point of view</b>, the system worked quite well.</li>
	<li>It is important to consider the situation <b>from the point of view of</b> the ordinary man in the street.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<p align="left"><b><i>3. To say what your opinion is about something </i></b><b>give / express / voice an opinion</b> to say what you think about something:</p>

<ul>
	<li>Other writers have <b>expressed</b> similar <b>opinions on</b> the subject.</li>
	<li>In his speech he was simply <b>voicing</b> an <b>opinion</b> that was held by many people at the time.</li>
	<li>The commission has yet to <b>give its opinion on</b> the matter.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<p align="left"><b>STUDY NOTE: Grammar </b></p>
<b>Express</b> and <b>voice an opinion</b> are more formal than <b>give an opinion</b>, but mean the same thing.
<p align="left"></p>
<b>make your views known (about something)</b> to tell people about your opinions, especially so that they can be considered when making decisions about something that affects you:
<ul>
	<li>Old people seldom have the opportunity to <b>make their views known</b>.</li>
</ul>
<h1>Giving Reasons</h1>
<h2>Giving Reasons</h2>
<p align="left">*see also <b>Causes</b>,  <b>Listing</b> and <b>Ordering</b></p>
<p align="left"></p>

<ol>
	<li>What you say when giving reasons for something</li>
	<li>Words meaning reason</li>
	<li>A reason that does not seem believable</li>
</ol>
<p align="left"></p>
<p align="left"><b><i>1. What you say when giving reasons for something </i></b></p>
<b>because</b> <i>conjunction</i> used when giving the reason for something:
<ul>
	<li>The idea was rejected <b>because</b> it was too expensive.</li>
	<li>They were discriminated against <b>because of</b> their colour.</li>
	<li><b>Because</b> many old people are on low incomes, they are often unable to afford adequate heating in the winter.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<p align="left"><b>STUDY NOTE: Grammar </b></p>
When writing essays, you don't usually use <b>because</b> at the beginning of a sentence when you are referring back to the previous sentence. For example, instead of writing "Many firms are building factories there. Because wages are much lower." it is much better to write: <i>Many firms are building factories there because wages are much lower</i>. But if the two sentences you want to connect are very long, you can write <b>The reason is</b> or <b>The reason for this is</b> at the start of a second sentence.
<p align="left"></p>
<b>the reason (for this) is</b> used when giving the reason for something, especially when the explanation is quite long:
<ul>
	<li>These printers quickly achieved a market share of over 60%. <b>The reason for this is</b> that the technology they use is much simpler — and therefore cheaper — and running costs are lower.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>why</b> <i>conjunction</i> used when writing about the reason that causes something to happen:
<ul>
	<li>No one knows <b>why</b> the dinosaurs died out so suddenly.</li>
	<li>There are many <b>reasons why</b> people are having fewer children.</li>
	<li>Girls mature earlier than boys. <b>This may explain why</b> they perform better at school.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>in order to</b> so that someone can do something, or so that something can happen:
<ul>
	<li>Many criminals steal <b>in order to</b> get money to buy drugs. (=the reason they steal is so that they can buy drugs)</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<p align="left"></p>
<p align="left"><b>STUDY NOTE: Grammar </b></p>
<b>In order to</b> is typically used in formal English. In less formal contexts, you often just use <b>to</b>, for example: I wanted to go to France <b>to</b> improve my knowledge of the language.
<p align="left"></p>
<b>for</b> <i>preposition</i> because of a particular reason:
<ul>
	<li>Most people go there <b>for</b> sightseeing.</li>
	<li>The names cannot be published <b>for</b> legal <b>reasons</b>.</li>
	<li>The data will be used <b>for</b> research <b>purposes</b>.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>through</b> <i>preposition</i> used when explaining why someone succeeded or failed:
<ul>
	<li>She got the job <b>through</b> hard work. (=because she worked very hard)</li>
	<li>The records were lost, either <b>through</b> carelessness or incompetence.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>as a result of</b> used when explaining what made something happen:
<ul>
	<li>Sea levels are rising <b>as a result of</b> global warming.</li>
	<li><b>As a result of</b> his work, illnesses such as tuberculosis can now be treated.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>due to / owing to</b> <i>preposition</i> used to give the reason why something has happened:
<ul>
	<li>She resigned <b>due to</b> ill health.</li>
	<li>The number of songbirds has declined. This is <b>partly due to</b> modern farming methods.</li>
	<li><b>Owing to</b> lack of public interest, the programme was abandoned.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<p align="left"><b><i>2. Words meaning reason </i></b></p>
<b>reason</b> <i>noun</i> [countable] why something happens or why someone does something:
<ul>
	<li>There were two main <b>reasons for</b> his success.</li>
	<li>39% of workers gave poor working conditions as <b>a reason for</b> leaving their previous job.</li>
	<li>The <b>reasons why</b> this happens are as follows.</li>
	<li>The <b>reason that</b> sales have not increased is that we had a very cold summer.</li>
	<li>There are <b>good reasons for</b> believing that the Earth has not increased in size during the past 500,000 years.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>explanation</b> <i>noun</i> [countable] a set of reasons that is intended to help you understand why something happens:
<ul>
	<li>Scientists have <b>offered</b> several possible <b>explanations for</b> these results.</li>
	<li>No one has ever really <b>provided</b> a satisfactory <b>explanation</b> of how children learn language.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>motive</b> <i>noun</i> [countable] the reason that makes someone decide to do something, especially something dishonest:
<ul>
	<li>There may have been a political <b>motive for</b> the killing.</li>
	<li>Some people have questioned the <b>motives behind</b> the decision.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>grounds</b> <i>noun</i> [plural] a reason that makes it right or fair for someone to do something.

You use grounds especially when saying that it seems justified to think that something is true, or when an action is justified according to official rules:
<ul>
	<li>There are strong <b>grounds</b> for believing that what he says is true.</li>
	<li>The latest crime statistics <b>provide</b> some <b>grounds for</b> optimism.</li>
	<li>He was refused permission to stay <b>on the grounds that</b> he had entered the country illegally. (=for that reason)</li>
	<li>They recommended joining the EU <b>on</b> purely economic <b>grounds</b>. (=only for economic reasons)</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>argument</b> <i>noun</i> [countable] a reason or set of reasons that someone uses to try to persuade another person to agree with them:
<ul>
	<li>There are <b>strong</b> environmental <b>arguments for</b> limiting car use.</li>
	<li>One of the main <b>arguments against</b> the death penalty is that an innocent person could accidentally be executed.</li>
	<li>I do not agree with the <b>argument that</b> experiments are necessary on live animals.</li>
	<li>There is little evidence to <b>support</b> their <b>argument</b>.</li>
	<li>He was the first person to <b>put forward</b> this <b>argument</b>. (=to suggest this set of reasons)</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>rationale</b> <i>noun</i> [countable usually singular] a series of reasons that someone uses to explain why they need to do something in a particular way:
<ul>
	<li>All organisations need a <b>rationale for</b> dividing up their work.</li>
	<li>In the first part of the book I will attempt to provide a <b>rationale</b> <b>for</b> such an approach.</li>
	<li>The document outlines the <b>rationale behind</b> the government's economic reforms.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>justification</b> <i>noun</i> [uncountable and countable] a reason why you think it is right to do something, especially something that seems wrong or unfair to other people:
<ul>
	<li>The US government's <b>main justification for</b> the war was that they wanted to bring democracy to the country.</li>
	<li><b>There is,</b> he states, <b>no justification for</b> killing another human being under any circumstances.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<p align="left"></p>
<p align="left"></p>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>basis</b> <i>noun</i> [countable] the main ideas, reasons, arguments etc on which something is based:
<ul>
	<li>There is no scientific <b>basis for</b> such beliefs.</li>
	<li>Piaget provided a theoretical <b>basis for</b> studying children's mental behaviour.</li>
	<li>Newton's work <b>forms the basis of</b> much of modern physics.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<p align="left"><b><i>3. A reason that does not seem believable </i></b></p>
<b>pretext</b> <i>noun</i> [countable] a false reason that someone gives in order to hide their real reason for doing something:
<ul>
	<li>They used religion as a <b>pretext for</b> their activities.</li>
	<li>People were sent to prison or labour camps <b>on the flimsiest of pretexts</b>. (=for reasons that seem very unlikely and difficult to believe)</li>
	<li>Police went into the area <b>under the pretext of</b> looking for drug dealers. (=using this as a reason)</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>excuse</b> <i>noun</i> [countable] a reason that you give to try to explain why you did something bad, especially one that is not true:
<ul>
	<li>Poverty should not be seen as an <b>excuse for</b> crime.</li>
	<li>The soldiers' <b>excuse</b> was <b>that</b> they were only obeying orders.</li>
	<li>People are tired of listening to the same old <b>feeble excuses</b>. (=excuses that seem very weak and not believable)</li>
</ul>
<h1>Increasing</h1>
<h2>Increasing</h2>
* opposite <b>Decreasing</b>
<p align="left"></p>

<ol>
	<li>To increase</li>
	<li>To make something increase</li>
	<li>An increase</li>
	<li>When something does not increase, or stops increasing</li>
</ol>
<p align="left"></p>
<p align="left"><b><i>1. To increase </i></b></p>
<b>increase</b> <i>verb</i> [intransitive] to become larger in number, amount, price, or value:
<ul>
	<li>Last year, the number of burglaries <b>increased by</b> 15 percent.</li>
	<li>The percentage of households with a computer <b>increased from</b> 32.9% to 52%.</li>
	<li>The world's population is<b> increasing at a rate of 91</b> million people each year.</li>
	<li>Land prices have <b>increased dramatically</b> during the last thirty years. (=by a surprisingly large amount)</li>
	<li>The ratio of women to men in management positions has been <b>increasing steadily</b>. (=more women are becoming managers)</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>rise / go up</b> <i>verb</i> [intransitive] phrasal verb to increase. <b>Rise</b> and <b>go up</b> are used especially about numbers, prices or temperatures. They can also be used about the level or standard of something:
<ul>
	<li>Fuel prices <b>rose by</b> over 10 percent.</li>
	<li>Last month unemployment <b>went up from</b> 1.6 million <b>to</b> just over 1.7 million.</li>
	<li>Crime rates have <b>risen sharply</b> in inner city areas. (=they have increased by a large amount in a short time)</li>
	<li>World demand for oil is <b>rising steadily</b> at around 2 percent a year.</li>
	<li>Sea temperatures have been <b>rising gradually</b> over the past 30 years.</li>
	<li>Living standards have <b>gone up dramatically</b>. (=by a surprisingly large amount)</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"><b> </b></p>
<p align="left"><b>STUDY NOTE: Grammar </b></p>
<b>Rise</b> is more formal than <b>go up</b>.

If you want to say that something 'has increased', you can say that it<b> is up</b>, for example: <i>Profits <b>are up by</b> almost 50%.</i>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>grow </b><i>verb</i> [intransitive] to increase, especially gradually over a period of time. <b>Grow</b> is used about numbers or amounts, or about the total amount of business or trade:
<ul>
	<li>The volume of traffic on our roads continues to <b>grow</b>.</li>
	<li>The economy is <b>growing by</b> about 2.5% a year.</li>
	<li>Since 1990, U.S. imports of foreign goods have <b>grown at a rate of</b> 7.7 percent per year.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>double / triple /quadruple</b> <i>verb</i> [intransitive] to become twice as much, three times as much, or four times as much:
<ul>
	<li>Since 1950, the number of people dying from cancer has almost <b>doubled</b>.</li>
	<li>During the last 15 years, earnings have <b>tripled</b> for men and <b>doubled</b> for women.</li>
	<li>The production of maize <b>quadrupled</b>.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>expand</b> <i>verb</i> [intransitive] to become larger in size, or to include a wider range of activities:
<ul>
	<li>After two years of no growth, the economy started to <b>expand</b> again in 2003.</li>
	<li>The report estimates that up to 40,000 plants could die out if the population <b>expands from</b> 6 billion to 8 billion by 2020, as currently predicted.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>soar</b> <i>verb</i> [intransitive] to increase and reach a very high level. Soar is used about numbers and amounts, or about people's feelings and attitudes, and is especially used in journalism:
<ul>
	<li>Interest rates <b>soared to</b> over 100 percent.</li>
	<li>The rumours <b>sent</b> house prices <b>soaring</b>. (=made them increase to a very high level) • The president's popularity <b>soared</b>. (=he became extremely popular)</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>escalate</b> <i>verb</i> [intransitive] to increase to a high level. <b>Escalate</b> is used about things that you do not want to increase such as costs, crimes, or violence:
<ul>
	<li>Energy costs have <b>escalated</b>.</li>
	<li>The violence began to <b>escalate</b> and the demonstrators started attacking the police.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<p align="left"><b>STUDY NOTE: Grammar </b></p>
The <b>-ing forms</b> of many of these verbs can also be used as adjectives, for example: the <b>increasing</b> demand for cheap goods
<ul>
	<li><b>rising</b> unemployment</li>
	<li>the <b>growing</b> problem of industrial pollution</li>
	<li><b>soaring</b> inflation</li>
	<li><b>escalating</b> fuel costs</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<p align="left"><b><i>2. To make something increase </i></b></p>
<b>increase</b> <i>verb</i> [transitive] to make something become larger in number, amount, price, or value:
<ul>
	<li>The company wants to <b>increase</b> the number of phones it sells in the UK.</li>
	<li>Smoking <b>increases</b> the risk of a heart attack <b>by</b> almost ten times.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>raise</b> <i>verb</i> [transitive] to increase prices, taxes, rents etc. <b>Raise</b> is also used about increasing levels and standards:
<ul>
	<li>The government will either have to <b>raise</b> taxes or reduce spending.</li>
	<li>The price of a barrel of oil was <b>raised</b> <b>to</b> over $30.</li>
	<li>The government says that it wants to <b>raise</b> standards in schools.</li>
	<li>Saturated fats, which are found mostly in animal products, <b>raise</b> the level of cholesterol in the blood.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"><b>STUDY NOTE: Grammar </b></p>
Don't confuse <b>rise</b> and <b>raise</b>. Don't say 'I don't think it would be a good idea to <span style="text-decoration:line-through;">rise</span> cigarette prices'. Say: <i>I don't think it would be a good idea to <b>raise</b> cigarette prices. </i><b>Raise</b> is more formal than <b>put up</b>.
<p align="left"></p>
<b>put up</b> <i>phrasal verb</i> to increase prices, taxes, rents etc:
<ul>
	<li>The company plans to <b>put up</b> the price of the drug by up to 20 percent.</li>
	<li>In the long term, unless the economy recovers, the government will be forced to <b>put up</b> taxes.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>double / triple / quadruple</b> <i>verb</i> [transitive] to increase the amount of something so that it is twice, three times, or four times as much:
<ul>
	<li>The United States has more than <b>doubled</b> the amount of aid it gives to developing countries.</li>
	<li>The company hopes to <b>triple</b> the size of its packaging business.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>expand</b> <i>verb</i> [transitive] to increase something so that it includes a wider range of things, or to increase the size of a business:
<ul>
	<li>The college is <b>expanding</b> its range of courses.</li>
	<li>Within a few months she <b>expanded</b> the business and took over a computer firm employing 120 people.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>boost</b> <i>verb</i> [transitive] to increase sales, profits, or the production of something, especially when they have been lower than you want them to be:
<ul>
	<li>Farmers can <b>boost</b> their profits by selling direct to customers.</li>
	<li>The hot weather has <b>boosted</b> sales of ice cream.</li>
	<li>Scientists are helping to <b>boost</b> rice production using genetically modified rice.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>extend</b> <i>verb</i> [transitive] to increase your power or influence, or to increase the number of things that you are involved in:
<ul>
	<li>The US wants to <b>extend</b> its influence in the region.</li>
	<li>Banks are <b>extending</b> the scope of their activities and are offering services such as insurance and advice on investments.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>step up</b> <i>phrasal verb</i> to increase your efforts or activities, especially in order to change a situation:
<ul>
	<li>The UN Security Council has <b>stepped up</b> the pressure on the Sudanese government to end the fighting.</li>
	<li>The organization is <b>stepping up</b> its campaign to persuade drivers to leave their cars at home and take public transport.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>add to</b> <i>phrasal verb</i> to cause something to increase in cost or value, or to cause a situation to become worse or more difficult:
<ul>
	<li>Rising fuel prices will <b>add to</b> the cost of basic goods.</li>
	<li>A new kitchen can <b>add to</b> the value of your home.</li>
	<li>The swarms of mosquitoes only <b>added to</b> their problems.</li>
	<li>Just <b>to add to the confusion</b>, there are several other common names for this plant.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<p align="left"><b><i>3. An increase </i></b></p>
<b>increase</b> <i>noun</i> [uncountable and countable] an occasion when the amount or number of something becomes bigger:
<ul>
	<li>There has been a <b>significant increase</b> in the number of people living alone.</li>
	<li>England's countryside is under threat from a <b>massive increase in</b> (=a very big increase) traffic.</li>
	<li>Profits rose by $2million. <b>This represents an increase of</b> 13.4 per cent compared to the previous year.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<p align="left"><b>STUDY NOTE: Grammar </b></p>
The usual preposition to use with <b>increase</b> is <b>in</b>. Don't say 'the increase of the earth's temperature'. Say: <i>the <b>increase in</b> the earth's temperature. You use <b>of</b> with numbers, for example: an increase of 15%.</i>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>growth</b> <i>noun</i> [singular, uncountable] an increase in the number, size, or importance of something. <b>Growth</b> is also used when saying that a company or a country's economy becomes more successful:
<ul>
	<li>There has been a <b>huge growth in </b>sales of big 4-wheel-drive vehicles.</li>
	<li>Many people are concerned about the <b>enormous growth in</b> the world's population.</li>
	<li>The astonishing <b>growth of</b> the Internet has had a dramatic effect on people's lives.</li>
	<li>Japan experienced a period of <b>rapid economic growth</b>.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>rise</b> <i>noun</i> [countable] an increase in the amount of something, or in the standard or level of something:
<ul>
	<li>The latest figures show a <b>sharp rise</b> (=a sudden big rise) in unemployment in the region.</li>
	<li>There was a 34 percent <b>rise in</b> the number of armed robberies.</li>
	<li>The majority of families experienced a <b>rise in</b> living standards.</li>
	<li>The instruments showed a <b>dramatic rise</b> (=a surprisingly large increase) <b>in</b> the level of radioactivity. Something was clearly going wrong.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<p align="left"><b>STUDY NOTE: Grammar </b></p>
In American English, a <b>raise</b> is an increase in someone's salary. In British English, this is usually referred to as a <b>pay rise</b>.
<p align="left"></p>
<b>build-up</b> <i>noun</i> [countable usually singular] a gradual increase in something harmful, dangerous, or worrying:
<ul>
	<li>The use of fossil fuels is causing a <b>build-up of</b> carbon dioxide in the atmosphere, which contributes to the greenhouse effect.</li>
	<li>She had <b>a build-up of</b> fluid on her knee.</li>
	<li>The crisis led to a big <b>military build-up</b>. (=the size of the army was greatly increased, especially in preparation for war)</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>surge</b> <i>noun</i> [countable usually singular] a sudden increase in something such as profits, demand, or interest:
<ul>
