	<li>There has been a big <b>surge in</b> demand for organically grown food.</li>
	<li>We have seen a tremendous <b>surge of</b> interest in Chinese medicine.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>explosion</b> <i>noun</i> [countable] a sudden very large increase in the amount or number of something:
<ul>
	<li>The country experienced a <b>population explosion</b>.</li>
	<li>There has been an <b>explosion in</b> the number of fast food restaurants.</li>
	<li>The book caused an <b>explosion of</b> interest in Renaissance Italy.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>boom</b> <i>noun</i> [singular] a sudden large increase in trade, profits or sales, with the result that a country, company, or industry becomes very successful. <b>Boom</b> is also used about a sudden increase in interest in something, with the result that it becomes very popular:
<ul>
	<li>the German <b>economic boom</b> of the 1960s</li>
	<li>the internet <b>boom</b></li>
	<li>There has been a <b>boom in</b> sales of diet books and videos.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<p align="left"></p>
<p align="left"><b><i>4. When something does not increase, or stops increasing </i></b></p>
<b>remain constant/stay the same</b> to continue to be at the same level or rate and not change:
<ul>
	<li>Her rate of breathing <b>remained constant</b>.</li>
	<li>The deer population has <b>remained constant</b> for many years.</li>
	<li>His weight <b>stayed the same</b>.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<p align="left"><b>STUDY NOTE: Grammar </b></p>
<p align="left"><b>Remain constant</b> is more formal than <b>stay the same</b>.</p>
<p align="left"><b> </b></p>
<b>peak / reach a peak</b> <i>verb</i> to stop increasing, after reaching a high level:
<ul>
	<li>Inflation <b>peaked at</b> 25%.</li>
	<li>The number of cases of the disease <b>reached its peak</b>.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>level off / out</b> <i>phrasal verb</i> to stop increasing, and remain at the same level:
<ul>
	<li>Car sales in Japan <b>levelled off</b> in September after months of continued growth.</li>
	<li>Statistics show that the number of work-related deaths appears to be <b>levelling off</b> <b>at</b></li>
</ul>
1.6 per 100,000 employees.
<h1>Linking Parts Of A Sentence</h1>
<h2>Linking Parts Of A Sentence</h2>
<ol>
	<li>Words meaning <b>'and'</b> or <b>'also'</b></li>
	<li>Words meaning <b>'because'</b></li>
	<li>Words meaning <b>'but'</b> or <b>'although'</b></li>
	<li>Words meaning <b>'if'</b></li>
	<li>Words meaning <b>'in order to'</b></li>
	<li>Words meaning <b>'or'</b></li>
	<li>Words meaning <b>'therefore' </b></li>
</ol>
<p align="left"><b> </b></p>
<p align="left"><b><i>1. Words meaning 'and' or 'also' </i></b></p>
<b>and</b> <i>conjunction</i> used when joining two words or clauses in one sentence, or in one part of a sentence:
<ul>
	<li>She studied physics <b>and</b> biology at university.</li>
	<li>The information was checked <b>and then</b> rechecked.</li>
	<li>His stay in London was <b>both</b> happy <b>and</b> successful.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<p align="left"><b>STUDY NOTE: Grammar </b></p>
Don't use <b>and</b> at the beginning of a sentence
<p align="left"></p>
<b>also</b> <i>adverb</i> used when adding another fact about someone or something, or when mentioning another person or thing:
<ul>
	<li>Smoking causes lung cancer. It has <b>also</b> been linked to heart disease.</li>
	<li>Although most of her books are for adults, she <b>also</b> writes for children.</li>
	<li>The country's mineral resources consist <b>not only</b> of diamonds <b>but also</b> of oil. (=used when you want to emphasize that something else is also important)</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<p align="left"><b>STUDY NOTE: Grammar </b></p>
Don't write 'also can'. For example, don't write '<span style="text-decoration:line-through;">You also can go </span>swimming, walking or cycling.' when you mean: <b>You can also go </b>swimming, walking or cycling.

Don't use <b>also</b> with two negative statements. Use <b>not</b> ... <b>either</b>. For example, don't write 'She does <b>not</b> drink. She <span style="text-decoration:line-through;">also</span> does <b>not</b> smoke.' when you mean: She does not drink.

She does <b>not</b> smoke <b>either</b>.
<p align="left"></p>
<b>too / as well</b> <i>adverb</i> used when you are adding another fact about someone or something:
<ul>
	<li>Wind energy is cheap. It is good for the environment <b>too</b>.</li>
	<li>The long hours at work began to affect his health. They affected his personal life <b>as well</b>.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<p align="left"><b>STUDY NOTE: Grammar </b></p>
<b>Too</b> and <b>as well </b>are normally used at the end of the sentence. The exception to this is the phrase <b>as well as</b>, which can be used earlier in the sentence, for example: <b><i>As well as</i></b><i> being an artist and designer, Morris was also a political thinker. </i>
<ul>
	<li>There are sports facilities available for girls <b>as well as</b> boys.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>in addition</b> used when adding another piece of information to what you have just said. <b>In addition</b> is often used when saying that something makes an amount even larger:
<ul>
	<li>A fifth of the world's population lives on less than $1 a day. <b>In addition</b>, over 100 million children are living on the streets.</li>
	<li>Over 600 people will lose their jobs, <b>in addition to</b> the 400 people who left the company last year.</li>
	<li><b>In addition to</b> being a major oil producer, Nigeria is home to over 110 million people.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"><b> </b></p>
<p align="left"><b>STUDY NOTE: Grammar </b></p>
<b>In</b> <b>addition</b>, <b>furthermore</b>, and <b>moreover</b> are very commonly used in essays.
<p align="left"></p>
<b>furthermore / moreover</b> <i>adverb</i> used at the beginning of a sentence when adding an important fact that is connected with what you have just said. <b>Furthermore</b> and <b>moreover</b> are formal words, used especially when trying to persuade people to agree with what you are saying:
<ul>
	<li>The drug has strong side effects. <b>Furthermore</b>, it can be addictive. (=the writer is adding another fact to persuade the reader that the drug is dangerous)</li>
	<li>There is no evidence to link him with the murder. <b>Moreover</b>, the murder weapon has still not been found. (=the writer is trying to persuade us that the police do not have very much information)</li>
	<li>Ireland's economy has grown far faster than those of its neighbors. <b>Moreover</b>, inflation has stayed low.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>not to mention</b> used when adding something at the end of a sentence, which adds to the main idea of what you have just said:
<ul>
	<li>As he got older, his films became very strange, <b>not to mention</b> violent.</li>
	<li>Big 4-wheel-drive vehicles cause so much environmental damage through pollution, <b>not to mention</b> the danger they pose to pedestrians and cyclists.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<p align="left"><b><i>2. Words meaning 'because' </i></b></p>
<b>because</b> conjunction used when giving the reason for something:
<ul>
	<li>People are leaving the countryside <b>because</b> they cannot find work there.</li>
	<li>The streets were flooded <b>because of</b> all the rain.</li>
	<li><b>Because</b> of the use of chemical fertilizers, there are fewer fish in our rivers.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<p align="left"><b>STUDY NOTE: Grammar </b></p>
In written English, you don't usually use <b>because</b> at the beginning of a sentence when you are referring back to the previous sentence. It is used to link two parts of the same sentence. For example, instead of writing "Many firms are building factories there. Because wages are much lower." it is much better to write: Many firms are building factories there<b>, because</b> wages are much lower.
<p align="left"></p>
<b>due to / owing to</b> <i>preposition</i> used to give the reason why something has happened:
<ul>
	<li>The delay was <b>due to</b> a problem with the ship's engines.</li>
	<li>Local authorities have been slow to build recycling facilities, <b>mainly owing to</b> lack of money.</li>
	<li>The men did most of the work in the fields. This was <b>partly due to the fact that </b>the men were stronger.</li>
	<li><b>Due to</b> the danger of fire, people are advised not to drop cigarettes on the ground.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>through</b> <i>preposition</i> because of something. <b>Through</b> is used especially when saying why someone succeeded or failed to do something:
<ul>
	<li>She succeeded <b>through</b> her own efforts.</li>
	<li>They managed to win the game,<b> partly through</b> luck and <b>partly through</b> skill.</li>
	<li>Thousands of working days are lost each year <b>through</b> illness.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>thanks to</b> used when explaining that something good has happened because of someone's efforts, or because something exists:
<ul>
	<li>Today, <b>thanks to</b> the Internet, people can do all their shopping from home.</li>
	<li><b>Thanks to</b> advances in modern medicine, the disease can now be cured.</li>
	<li>Reinhardt survived the war, <b>mainly thanks to</b> the help of a German officer who loved his music.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>since</b> (also <b>as</b> British English) <i>conjunction</i> used when giving the reason why someone decides to do something or decides that something is true:
<ul>
	<li>As it was a hot day, they decided to leave all the windows open.</li>
	<li>Since it is difficult to predict how the climate will change, it is not possible to say which countries will suffer the most.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>in view of</b> a formal phrase used when introducing the reason for someone's decision, or when saying that something is an important thing to consider:
<ul>
	<li>The court decided that <b>in view of</b> his age, he should be released.</li>
	<li><b>In view of</b> all the research on the subject, it seems strange that so many people still smoke cigarettes.</li>
	<li>Most British people do not want to change from the pound to the Euro. This may seem surprising <b>in view of the fact</b> that they often use Euros on their holidays.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>out of</b> <i>preposition</i> because of a particular feeling or quality:
<ul>
	<li>He started reading the book <b>out of curiosity</b>.</li>
	<li>She asked the question <b>out of politeness</b>.</li>
	<li><b>Out of desperation</b>, he tried to borrow money from his neighbour.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<p align="left"><b><i>3. Words meaning 'but' or 'although' </i></b></p>
<b>but</b> <i>conjunction</i> used when linking two words or phrases that seem opposite or very different in meaning:
<ul>
	<li>The plant's leaves are big, <b>but</b> its flowers are quite small.</li>
	<li>Her books are fascinating <b>but</b> often rather disturbing.</li>
	<li>Many French dishes are basically simple, <b>but</b> they can take a long time to prepare.</li>
	<li>Most of us value human life, <b>but</b> some people think of animals as being equally important.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>although</b> <i>conjunction</i> used when contrasting one clause with another in the same sentence:
<ul>
	<li><b>Although</b> you are in the middle of the city, you feel as if you are in the countryside.</li>
	<li>The windmill is still in good working order, <b>although</b> it has not been used since the 1950s.</li>
	<li><b>Although</b> lack of sleep causes some problems, it has a relatively small effect on performance at work.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>however / nevertheless</b> <i>conjunction</i> used when saying something that seems very different or surprising after your previous statement. <b>However</b> and <b>nevertheless</b> are usually used when referring back to the previous sentence:
<ul>
	<li>Their economy was incredibly successful in the 1980s. Since then, <b>however</b>, there has been a big rise in unemployment.</li>
	<li>The town is a long way from the nearest big city. <b>However</b>, there is a good bus service. • A series of studies 20 years ago suggested that there was a link between watching violent films and violent behaviour. <b>Nevertheless</b>, the results remain highly controversial.</li>
	<li>It was very hard digging in the dry ground, but the work was satisfying <b>nevertheless</b>.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<p align="left"><b>STUDY NOTE: Grammar </b></p>
<b>However</b> is usually used in the middle of a sentence, separated from the rest of the sentence by commas:: <i>Jack and his family managed to escape before the soldiers arrived. Other families in the village, <b>however</b>, were less lucky.</i>

Or it comes at the beginning of a sentence: <i>He began his academic career as a mathematician. <b>However</b>, his main achievements were in the field of nuclear physics</i>.  <b>Nevertheless</b> is usually used at the beginning of a sentence, or at the end.
<p align="left"></p>
<b>whereas / while</b> <i>conjunction</i> used when making comparisons and saying that something is true of one person, thing, or situation, but it is different for another. <b>Whereas</b> and <b>while</b> are used when contrasting one clause with another in the same sentence:
<ul>
	<li>Taxes make up 62% of the price of a litre of petrol in France, <b>whereas</b> in Britain, the tax is 75%.</li>
	<li>Some people visit their doctor once every few weeks, <b>while</b> others may not visit a doctor for several years.</li>
	<li><b>Whereas</b> in most of the world they drive on the right, in the UK and Japan they drive on the left.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>by contrast</b> used when making comparisons and saying that a person, thing, or situation is very different from the one you have just mentioned. <b>By contrast</b> is used when referring back to the previous sentence:
<ul>
	<li>The surface temperature on Venus is higher than the boiling point of water. Mars, <b>by contrast</b>, is very cold</li>
	<li>A report by the FBI shows that 26% of female murder victims in 1995 were killed by their husbands or boyfriends. By contrast, only 3% of male victims were killed by their wives or girlfriends.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>yet</b> <i>conjunction</i> used when introducing a fact that seems surprising after what you have just said:
<ul>
	<li>Last summer there was a drought, <b>yet</b> some people were still watering their gardens every day.</li>
	<li>We all know that fibre is important for good health. <b>And yet</b> all the natural fibre is removed from many foods such as white bread and sugar.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>even so</b> used when saying that something is true, in spite of a fact that you have just mentioned:
<ul>
	<li>Morris's furniture is distinctly English. <b>Even so</b>, the sale drew a lot of American interest. • The economy continues to do well, but <b>even so</b>, many analysts are predicting a slowdown in the near future.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>in spite of / despite</b> <i>preposition</i> even though something happens or is true:
<ul>
	<li>This was a dinosaur that weighed only 10 tons, <b>in spite of</b> being some 28 metres long.</li>
	<li><b>In spite of everything</b> that has happened, life is still getting better for many Russians.</li>
	<li><b>Despite</b> his lack of formal education, he became one of the world's leading mathematicians.</li>
	<li>Many people are worried that cellphones may be dangerous to health, <b>despite the fact that</b> most of the research suggests that there is little risk.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<p align="left"><b><i>4. Words meaning 'if' </i></b></p>
<b>if</b> <i>conjunction</i> used when talking about the possibility that something might happen or be true:
<ul>
	<li><b>If</b> the scientists' predictions are correct, average global temperatures could rise by 6 degrees.</li>
	<li>He faced a long prison sentence <b>if</b> the court found him guilty.</li>
	<li>The report said that the accident could have been avoided <b>if</b> the correct safety procedures had been followed.</li>
	<li>Most countries are prepared to use force, <b>if necessary</b>, to protect their national interests.</li>
	<li>The patient should be kept in the same position, <b>if possible</b>.</li>
	<li>The injury needed to be treated immediately. <b>If not</b>, infection could set in.</li>
	<li>The British authorities could not help, <b>even if</b> they wanted to.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<p align="left"><b>STUDY NOTE: Grammar </b></p>
When using <b>if</b> to <b>talk about the future</b>, you normally <b>use the simple present tense</b>. For example, don't say <span style="text-decoration:line-through;">'If it will rain</span>, the game will be canceled', when you mean: <b>If it rains,</b> the game will be canceled.
<p align="left"></p>
<b>unless</b> <i>conjunction</i> if something does not happen, or if someone does not do something:
<ul>
	<li><b>Unless</b> something is done quickly, developing countries will fall even further behind Western countries.</li>
	<li>The star is really difficult to see <b>unless</b> the sky is dark and very clear.</li>
	<li>The doctors said they could not treat the boy <b>unless and until</b> his parents gave their permission.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>whether or not</b> used when saying that it does not matter if something happens or not, or if something is true or not:
<ul>
	<li>Research showed that six out of 10 patients got better on their own, <b>whether or not</b> they received treatment.</li>
	<li><b>Whether or not</b> you agree with what she is saying, her articles are always interesting and thought-provoking.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>otherwise</b> <i>adverb</i> used when saying that there will be a bad result if someone does not do something, or if something does not happen:
<ul>
	<li>The committee needs to act quickly, <b>otherwise</b> there could be a serious problem.</li>
	<li>The local people are certainly glad that the tourists are there. <b>Otherwise</b> there would be no money and no jobs.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>in case</b> in order to deal with something that might happen:
<ul>
	<li>Doctors have to take out insurance to protect themselves <b>in case</b> they are sued.</li>
	<li>It is best to keep a medical kit ready <b>in case of emergency</b>.</li>
	<li>She did not think it would rain, but she took her umbrella <b>just in case</b>.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>assuming that</b> if what you think will happen is true:
<ul>
	<li><b>Assuming that</b> the present trend continues, the world population is likely to rise to over 8 billion.</li>
	<li>This sort of floor covering can be laid directly onto concrete floors, <b>assuming that</b> they are level.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>as long as / provided that</b> <i>conjunction</i> only if something else happens or is true:
<ul>
	<li>Vegetarian diets are perfectly healthy, <b>provided that</b> you take care to get enough iron, calcium and B vitamins.</li>
	<li><b>As long as </b>the economy continues to grow, people will continue to support the government.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>on condition that</b> used when you agree to do something only if someone first agrees to do something else:
<ul>
	<li>He was offered the job <b>on condition that</b> he went on a month-long training course.</li>
	<li>The painting was sold <b>on condition that</b> it never left France.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>in the event of / that</b> if something happens, especially a serious situation such as an accident, a fire, or a war:
<ul>
	<li>Guidelines have been isued to local authorities on what to do <b>in the event of </b>a nuclear accident.</li>
	<li><b>In the event of</b> an earthquake, people are advised to take cover under desks or doorways.</li>
	<li><b>In the event that</b> the party lost the election, his future as party leader would be in doubt.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b><i>5. Words meaning 'in order to' </i></b><b>in order to</b> for the purpose of doing something:
<ul>
	<li>Some people steal <b>in order to</b> buy drugs.</li>
	<li><b>In order to</b> prove his theory, he carried out a series of experiments.</li>
	<li>Plants need light <b>in order to</b> survive.</li>
	<li>The speech was changed <b>in order not to</b> offend anyone.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<p align="left"><b>STUDY NOTE: Grammar </b></p>
<b>in order to</b> is used especially in formal contexts. In all other contexts people often just write <b>to</b>, for example: The organization was set up originally <b>to</b> protect the rights of children.
<ul>
	<li><b>To</b> make sure that the job was done properly, Mr Lobov appointed three new deputy ministers.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>so (that)</b> <i>conjunction</i> used when saying why someone does something or what the result of something is:
<ul>
	<li>Workers need to learn new skills so that they can keep up with the latest advances in technology.</li>
	<li>Doctors use miniature cameras so that they can see inside the patients' stomachs.</li>
	<li>The windows are designed so that you can see out, but other people cannot see in.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>for</b> <i>preposition</i> for a particular reason or purpose:
<ul>
	<li>She went into hospital <b>for</b> a checkup.</li>
	<li>Some people give up eating meat <b>for</b> health <b>reasons</b>, while others give up because they are concerned about animal welfare.</li>
	<li>The land is used <b>for</b> agricultural <b>purposes</b>.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>with the aim of doing something</b> in order to try and achieve something:
<ul>
	<li>The dam was built <b>with the aim of</b> providing drinking water to thousands of people.</li>
	<li>Talks were held in Paris <b>with the aim of</b> helping the two sides reach an agreement.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>with a view to doing something</b> because you are planning to do something later in the future, and this will help you to do it:
<ul>
	<li>They wanted to establish closer links with Germany, <b>with a view to</b> becoming members of the European Union.</li>
	<li>Rice and potatoes were genetically modified, <b>with a view to</b> commercial planting.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<p align="left"><b><i>6. Words meaning 'or' </i></b></p>
<b>or</b> <i>conjunction</i> used between two possibilities or choices, or before the last one in a list of possibilities or choices:
<ul>
	<li>It is important not to get the chemicals on your hands <b>or</b> your clothes.</li>
	<li>Payment can be made by cash, cheque <b>or</b> credit card.</li>
	<li>There is very little difference between the two species of bird, <b>either</b> in size <b>or</b> colour. <b>alternatively</b> <i>adverb</i> used when giving another choice apart from the one you have already mentioned:</li>
	<li>You can go up into the mountains. <b>Alternatively</b>, you can stroll around one of Switzerland's delightful cities where the old mixes with the new.</li>
	<li>For a master's degree, 12 months' full-time study is normally required, or <b>alternatively</b> 24 months of part-time study.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>on the one hand ... on the other (hand)</b> used when giving two very different ideas or opinions about something, especially when they need to be balanced against each other:
<ul>
	<li><b>On the one hand</b>, the internet gives students access to information on every imaginable topic. <b>On the other</b>, there is a lot of material on the internet that is very unsuitable for students.</li>
	<li><b>On the one hand</b>, it is important not to limit individual freedom too much, <b>but on the other hand</b>, people have the right to be able to live their lives in peace.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<p align="left"><b>STUDY NOTE: Grammar </b></p>
Don't say <span style="text-decoration:line-through;">'on one hand'</span>. Say <b>on the one hand</b>.
<p align="left"></p>
<p align="left"><b><i>7. Words meaning 'therefore' </i></b></p>
<b>therefore </b><i>adverb</i> used when saying that something happens or someone does something as a result of something else:
<ul>
	<li>She already had a lot of experience and <b>therefore</b> seemed the best candidate for the job.</li>
	<li>Many old people have some form of disability or health problem. It is not surprising, <b>therefore</b>, that they are the biggest users of the health care system.</li>
	<li>The Japanese writing system has thousands of characters. <b>Therefore</b> it takes a long time to learn.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<p align="left"><b>STUDY NOTE: Grammar </b></p>
<b>Therefore</b> is more formal than <b>so.</b>

You can use <b>therefore</b> in the middle of a sentence, or at the beginning of a sentence. You use <b>so</b> in the middle of a sentence, usually after a comma.
<p align="left"></p>
<b>so </b><i>conjunction</i> used when saying that something happens or someone does something as a result of something else:
<ul>
	<li>They had not eaten all day, <b>so</b> they were very hungry.</li>
	<li>Questions have been raised over the safety of the toys, <b>and so</b> they are being withdrawn from the market.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>thus </b><i>adverb</i> a formal word, meaning as a result of what you have just mentioned:
<ul>
	<li>The dinosaurs all died out within a short period of time. <b>Thus</b> it seems likely that there must have been some kind of catastrophic event.</li>
	<li>The program is very simple <b>and thus</b> easy to run.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<p align="left"><b>STUDY NOTE: Grammar </b></p>
<b>Thus</b> is more formal than <b>therefore</b>, and is used especially in formal writing.
<p align="left"></p>
<b>hence</b> <i>adverb</i> a formal word, meaning for this reason:
<ul>
	<li>This material is highly poisonous, <b>hence</b> the importance of careful handling.</li>
	<li>Their names sound very similar. <b>Hence</b> they are often confused with each other.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>as a result </b>use this to say that because of a particular situation, something else happens or is true:
<ul>
	<li>Some people suffer from stress at work and become ill <b>as a result</b>.</li>
	<li>The farmer could not pump water onto his field and, <b>as a result</b>, he had grown only twenty tons of melons compared to eighty before the war.</li>
	<li>Economic growth slowed down <b>as a result of</b> inflation.</li>
	<li><b>As a result of</b> her injuries, she was forced to abandon her hopes of going to medical school.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>consequently / as a consequence </b><i>adverb</i> use this to say that because of a particular situation, something else happens or is true:
<ul>
	<li>The disease attacks the plant, the flower does not open, and <b>consequently</b> no seeds are produced.</li>
	<li>More people are using their cars, and <b>as a consequence</b> many rural bus services have been severely reduced.</li>
	<li><b>As a consequence of</b> global warming, our climate is already starting to change.</li>
	<li>Lead remains forever in the atmosphere. <b>Consequently</b>, this year's lead pollution will add to that of all previous years.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<p align="left"><b>STUDY NOTE: Grammar </b></p>
<p align="left"><b>Consequently</b> and <b>as a consequence</b> are more formal than <b>as a result</b>.</p>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>for this reason / for these reasons </b>used when explaining the reason for something:
<ul>
	<li>She was not very good at ball games. <b>For this reason</b> she did not care much for sport or physical activities.</li>
	<li>If you live in a big city, housing is very expensive and there is so much pollution<b>. For these and other reasons</b>, more and more people are choosing to move out to the country.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>with the result that </b>use this to say that because of a particular situation, another situation exists or happens:
<ul>
	<li>Both laboratories were completely re-equipped last year, <b>with the result that</b> we now have the most modern facilities in the country.</li>
	<li>Taxes were increased, with the result that people had to work harder if they wanted to maintain their standard of living.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>this means that</b> used when saying what the result of something is:
<ul>
	<li>Childcare is very expensive. <b>This means that</b> many women cannot afford to go back to work after having children.</li>
	<li>If students arrive late, <b>this</b> can <b>mean that</b> a large part of the lesson time is wasted.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>thereby</b> <i>adverb</i> a formal word, used when saying what the result of something is. You use <b>thereby</b> in the middle of a sentence, usually after a comma:
<ul>
	<li>The two companies were merged, <b>thereby</b> creating a single company.</li>
	<li>If our homes are properly insulated, we need to use less oil or gas, <b>thereby</b> cutting the cost of heating them.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>accordingly</b> <i>adverb</i> a formal word, meaning as a result of what you have just said:
<ul>
	<li>Too much alcohol can be harmful to health. <b>Accordingly</b>, on this diet you are allowed only one or two units of alcohol per day.</li>
	<li>He had disobeyed an order from a senior officer, and <b>accordingly</b> he was dismissed from the army.</li>
</ul>
<h1>Listing &amp; Ordering</h1>
<h2>Listing &amp; Ordering</h2>
1. What you say when ordering a group of things that you want to mention 2. Ways of introducing a list of reasons, causes, points etc
<p align="left"></p>
<p align="left"><b><i>1. What you say when ordering a group of things that you want to mention </i></b></p>
<b>firstly / first</b> <i>adverb</i> used when mentioning the first in a list of reasons, arguments, or parts of an essay:
<ul>
	<li>There are two main reasons why people choose this type of investment. <b>Firstly</b>, it is relatively safe. Secondly, it offers a good rate of interest.</li>
	<li>The statistics show, <b>firstly</b>, that crime is increasing; secondly, that most crime is committed by young men; and lastly, that many of these young men are on drugs.</li>
	<li>This essay seeks to answer the following questions. <b>First</b>, is our current political system truly democratic? Second, what are the alternatives?</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>first of all</b> used especially when the first thing that you mention is the most important thing:
<ul>
	<li>The content of the article must, <b>first of all</b>, be useful to the reader.</li>
	<li>People are living longer for several reasons. <b>First of all</b>, there have been enormous advances in medical science. Secondly, our diets are now much healthier.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>secondly / second</b> <i>adverb</i> used when mentioning the second in a list of reasons, arguments, or parts of an essay:
<ul>
	<li>Many people are concerned about the problems associated with nuclear energy. Firstly, what do you do with all the nuclear waste? <b>Secondly</b>, how can we prevent nuclear materials from falling into the hands of terrorists?</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>thirdly / third</b> <i>adverb</i> used when mentioning the third in a list of reasons, arguments, or parts of an essay:
<ul>
	<li>There are many things we can do to help protect our environment. First of all, we can use our cars less. Secondly, we can recyle more. <b>Thirdly</b>, we need to develop new sources of energy which cause less pollution.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>in the first / second / third place</b> means the same as <b>firstly</b>, <b>secondly</b> or <b>thirdly</b>, but is less formal. It is used especially when giving reasons or examples:
<ul>
	<li>Modern communications have completely changed the way we work. <b>In the first place</b>, they have made it possible for many people to work from home. They also allow people in different parts of the world to communicate instantly at any time of day.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<p align="left"><b>STUDY NOTE: Grammar </b></p>
When you are giving a long list of reasons or parts in an essay, it sounds rather repetitive to say <b>Firstly</b>... <b>Secondly</b>... <b>Thirdly</b> ... <b>Fourthly</b>... <b>Fifthly</b> etc. It sounds much more natural to vary the language and use other phrases instead of numbers, for example <b>In addition</b> ... <b>Furthermore/moreover</b> ... <b>Lastly</b> ...

Here is an example of this kind of ordering: There are many reasons for switching to wind power. <b>Firstly</b>, it causes much less damage to the environment than fossil fuels such as oil and coal. <b>In addition</b>, wind power comes from a renewable energy source, and there will always be more wind available. <b>Furthermore</b>, wind turbines and windmills are much more graceful and attractive to look at than power stations. <b>Last but not least</b>, they are very cheap to run.
<p align="left"></p>
<b>then / next</b> <i>adverb</i> used when saying what happens next in a process:
<ul>
	<li>First, we added the salt to the water, <b>then</b> we boiled the mixture for five minutes.</li>
	<li>Take the fish and gently rub oil over it. <b>Next</b>, place it in a medium hot oven for 15 minutes.</li>
	<li>When you receive the equipment, you need to check that all the parts are there. <b>Then</b> you need to connect it to the electricity supply.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>in addition</b> as well as what you have already mentioned:
<ul>
	<li>Fast foods and snacks have been linked to obesity. <b>In addition</b>, studies have shown that these foods can cause behavioural problems in young children.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>furthermore / moreover</b> <i>adverb</i> as well as what you have already mentioned.

These are formal words which are used especially when suggesting that what you are saying is just as important or even more important than what you have already said:
<ul>
	<li>In order to keep the price of the book down, we have used fewer photographs than we wanted to. <b>Furthermore</b>, the book has no colour, which means that we have been limited to black and white images.</li>
	<li>Older workers often have a great deal of experience to offer. <b>Moreover</b>, they are extremely reliable and less likely to change jobs.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>lastly</b> <i>adverb</i> used when something is the last of the things that you want to mention:
<ul>
	<li>The island has become very popular, firstly for its beautiful beaches, secondly because of its friendly atmosphere, and <b>lastly</b> because it is so easy to get to from the UK.</li>
	<li>There are many reasons why prison doesn't work. First of all, prisons often act as training colleges for criminals. Secondly, prison does not deal with the reasons why young men commit crime. <b>Lastly</b>, it costs huge amounts of money to keep people in prison.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>finally</b> <i>adverb</i> used when something is the last thing that you want to say, especially at the end of a long essay, report etc. You also use <b>finally</b> when giving the last reason, example etc in a long list:
<ul>
	<li><b>Finally</b>, I would like to suggest some possible solutions to the problem.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>one last / final point</b> used when you want to add one last thing to what you have already said, for example at the end of the final paragraph of your essay:
<ul>
	<li><b>One final point</b> to remember is that although regular exercise is usually good for health, too much exercise can actually cause permanent damage to muscles and joints.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<p align="left"><b><i>2. Ways of introducing a list of reasons, causes, points etc </i></b></p>
<b>there are several / there are a number of</b> … used when you are going to list several reasons, causes, points etc:
<ul>
	<li><b>There are several</b> points to keep in mind when writing business letters: try to be brief, always be polite, and make sure that you use the correct job title.</li>
	<li>Women are more likely to suffer from depression than men. <b>There are a number of</b> reasons for this.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<p align="left"><b>STUDY NOTE: Grammar </b></p>
When you are introducing a list, you can either use a colon (<b>:</b>) before the list, or a full stop (<b>.</b>).
<p align="left"></p>
<b>as follows</b> used when introducing a list or an explanation:
<ul>
	<li>The objectives of the study are <b>as follows</b>: firstly to find out whether there was a demand for this type of service, and secondly to establish how much people were willing to pay for it.</li>
	<li>The facts are <b>as follows</b>. Kennedy was shot by a lone gunman named Lee Harvey Oswald. While Oswald was being held in custody, he was shot by Jack Ruby.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>the following</b> <i>adjective</i>, noun [singular] used when referring to the things or people that you are going to mention:
<ul>
	<li><b>The following</b> foods are high in fat: butter, cream, cheese, pastry, and any kind of fried food.</li>
	<li><b>The following</b> is a brief summary of the main sources of grants for postgraduate students.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<p align="left"></p>
<p align="left"><b>STUDY NOTE: Grammar </b></p>
<b>Following</b> can be used as an adjective, for example: <b>the following</b> example, or as a noun, for example: Benefits include <b>the following</b>.
<h1>Making Generalizations</h1>
<h2>Making Generalizations</h2>
1 .Ways of saying that something is true about most people or things 2 .To say that something is true about most people or things
<p align="left"></p>
<p align="left"><b><i>1 .Ways of saying that something is true about most people or things </i></b></p>
<b>most</b> <i>determiner, pron</i> used when saying that something is true about the majority of people or things in a group, or about the majority of something:
<ul>
	<li><b>Most</b> people would agree that the law needs changing.</li>
	<li><b>In most cases</b> the patient makes a full recovery. (=most patients recover completely)</li>
	<li><b>Most of</b> (=most people or things in a group) the class are women.</li>
	<li><b>Most of</b> the research supports this point of view.</li>
	<li>The students speak English <b>most of the time</b> when they are at school.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>mostly / mainly / largely</b> <i>adverb</i> used when saying that something is true about most of a group of people or things, or about most of something:
<ul>
	<li>The people who use the service are <b>mostly</b> businessmen.</li>
	<li>The cars are <b>mostly for</b> export.</li>
	<li>Apart from the Nile valley, Egypt is <b>mostly</b> desert.</li>
	<li>The audience were <b>mainly</b> young people in their teens.</li>
	<li>The disease <b>mainly</b> affects women.</li>
	<li>Their attempts were <b>largely</b> unsuccessful.</li>
	<li>Half of the country's people faced starvation, <b>largely as a result of</b> the civil war.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<p align="left"><b>STUDY NOTE: Grammar </b></p>
<b>Largely</b> sounds more formal than <b>mostly</b> or <b>mainly</b>, and is used especially in written English.
<p align="left"></p>
<b>predominantly</b> <i>adverb</i> used when saying that most people or things in a group are of a particular type:
<ul>
	<li>Engineering has traditionally been a <b>predominantly</b> male profession. (=most engineers are men)</li>
	<li>At that time England was a <b>predominantly</b> agricultural society.</li>
	<li>The condition <b>predominantly</b> affects middle-aged women.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>almost all / nearly all / virtually all</b> <i>adverb</i> used when you want to emphasize that there are very few exceptions:
<ul>
	<li>Unemployment rates went up in <b>almost all</b> European countries.</li>
	<li>The study found that <b>in almost all cases</b> people were satisfied with the service they received.</li>
	<li>The country has to import <b>almost all of</b> its oil.</li>
	<li><b>Nearly all</b> the children interviewed said that they are worried about what will happen in the future.</li>
	<li>Magnesium is found in <b>virtually all</b> foods.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<p align="left"><b>STUDY NOTE: Grammar </b></p>
Don't say 'the most people/things', when you mean 'most people/things'. For example, don't say 'The most people live in towns', when you mean: Most people live in towns.
<p align="left"></p>
<b>the majority</b> <i>noun</i> [singular] more than half of a group of the people or things in a large group:
<ul>
	<li><b>The majority of</b> crimes are never reported to the police.</li>
	<li><b>The vast majority of</b> Algerians are Muslim. (=almost all Algerians are Muslim)</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"><b> </b></p>
<p align="left"><b>STUDY NOTE: Grammar </b></p>
<b>The majority of</b> is usually followed by a countable noun in the plural, but sometimes it can be followed by an uncountable noun which refers to a group of things or people: <i>Can the president order a military operation in another country <b>if the majority of</b> the legislature opposes the action? </i>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>in general</b> used when saying that something is true about most of a group of people or things:
<ul>
	<li>Men, <b>in general</b>, are just as good at looking after children as women.</li>
	<li><b>In general,</b> teenagers from poor families are less likely to go to university.</li>
	<li><b>In general,</b> smaller firms are more flexible.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>generally</b> <i>adverb</i> used when saying that something is true about most of a group of people or things. <b>Generally</b> is also used when saying that most people have a particular opinion:
<ul>
	<li><b>Generally</b>, part-time workers receive lower wages than full-time workers.</li>
	<li>People <b>generally</b> are living longer.</li>
	<li>Newton <b>is generally regarded as</b> the father of modern science.</li>
	<li><b>It is</b> now <b>generally accepted that</b> even the smallest dose of radiation carries a health risk.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>generally speaking / broadly speaking / as a rule</b> used when making general statements about what usually happens or is usually true:
<ul>
	<li><b>Generally speaking</b>, female workers are less likely to strike.</li>
	<li>People in the US are, <b>generally speaking</b>, not very well informed about international politics.</li>
	<li><b>As a rule</b>, snakes have simple teeth, all roughly the same shape.</li>
	<li>The surface of Mercury, <b>broadly speaking</b>, can be divided into two types of land area.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>for the most part</b> used when saying that something is true in most cases, but not in every case:
<ul>
	<li>These problems have, <b>for the most part</b>, been resolved.</li>
	<li><b>For the most part</b>, local people welcomed the plan.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>by and large / in the main / on the whole</b> used when saying that something is true in most ways, or in most cases:
<ul>
	<li>The scheme was <b>by and large</b> a success.</li>
	<li><b>On the whole</b>, the system worked well.</li>
	<li>The people <b>on the whole</b> were very friendly.</li>
	<li>The pictures are, <b>in the main</b>, portraits.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<p align="left"><b><i>2. To say that something is true about most people or things </i></b></p>
<b>generalize</b> <i>verb</i> [intransitive] to make a general statement, in which you say that something is true about most people or things:
<ul>
	<li>It is clearly a mistake to <b>generalize from</b> only a few examples.</li>
	<li>It is difficult to <b>generalize about</b> the American police, because there are over 40,000 police departments in the US.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>generalization</b> <i>noun</i> [countable] a statement in which you say that something is true about most people or things:
<ul>
	<li>Social scientists try to <b>make generalizations</b> about society, based on the best available evidence.</li>
	<li>A lot of misleading <b>generalizations</b> have been <b>made</b> about the differences between men and women.</li>
	<li>English people love animals. As a <b>broad generalization</b>, there is much truth in this statement. (=a generalization which has many exceptions, but which gives you a general idea about a group of people or things)</li>
	<li>When people say things like "the theatre is for everyone", this seems rather a <b>sweeping generalization.</b> (=a statement that seems exaggerated and likely to be wrong)</li>
</ul>
<h1>Problems &amp; Solutions</h1>
<h2>Problems &amp; Solutions</h2>
<ol>
	<li>Problems</li>
	<li>Small problems</li>
	<li>Solutions</li>
</ol>
<p align="left"></p>
<p align="left"><b><i>1. Problems </i></b></p>
<b>problem</b> <i>noun</i> [countable] a situation that must be dealt with because it is causing harm or inconvenience, or because it is stopping you from doing what you want to do:
<ul>
	<li>Britain <b>faced</b> enormous economic and social <b>problems</b> after the war.</li>
	<li>Classroom discipline is a <b>serious problem</b> in many schools.</li>
	<li>A special force was set up to try to <b>deal with</b> the <b>problem</b> of gun crime.</li>
	<li>The sooner this <b>problem</b> is <b>solved</b> (=successfully dealt with), the better.</li>
	<li>The US government needs to do more to help <b>tackle</b> the <b>problem</b> (=deal with the problem) of global warming.</li>
	<li>It is in everyone's interest to <b>address</b> the <b>problem</b> (=find ways of solving the problem) of global poverty.</li>
	<li>The engineers say that they have <b>fixed</b> all the technical <b>problems</b> that could have caused the accident.</li>
	<li>Professor Murray believes <b>that the root of the problem lies</b> (=the origin of the problem is) in a basic fault in the car's design.</li>
	<li><b>Problems</b> can <b>arise</b> (=problems can happen) when people try to defend themselves in court without help from a lawyer.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>issue</b> <i>noun</i> [countable] a problem that needs to be dealt with, or a subject that is important and needs to be discussed:
<ul>
	<li>International terrorism is the <b>biggest issue</b> (=the most important issue) <b>facing</b> the world today.</li>
	<li>Security is an <b>important issue</b> when buying things on the internet.</li>
	<li>Previous governments failed to <b>address</b> (=try to deal with) social <b>issues</b> such as unemployment and homelessness.</li>
	<li>The <b>issue</b> can only be <b>resolved</b> (=be successfully dealt with) through negotiation between the two sides.</li>
	<li>Nuclear power is a <b>highly controversial issue</b> (=one that causes a lot of public argument and disagreement) in the UK.</li>
	<li>Immigration could be a <b>key issue</b> (=a very important issue) at the next election.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<p align="left"><b>STUDY NOTE: Grammar </b></p>
<b>Issue</b> is used especially about problems that affect a lot of people in society. It is also often used instead of the word <b>problem</b> because it sounds less negative.
<p align="left"></p>
<b>challenge</b> <i>noun</i> [countable] something difficult that you must do or deal with, which needs a lot of skill, effort, and determination:
<ul>
	<li>Understanding the brain is one of the <b>biggest challenges</b> in science.</li>
	<li>She said she was looking forward to the <b>challenge</b> of starting up a new business on her own.</li>
	<li>The Colombian government knows that it <b>faces</b> huge <b>challenges</b> if it is to win the war on drugs.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<p align="left"><b>STUDY NOTE: Grammar </b></p>
<b>Challenge</b> is used especially when talking about something that sounds exciting and interesting, because it will take a lot of effort and skill.
<p align="left"></p>
<b>difficulty</b> <i>noun</i> [countable usually plural, uncountable] a problem that makes it more difficult to do something that you are trying to do:
<ul>
	<li>The company has managed to <b>overcome</b> (=deal with) its recent <b>financial</b> <b>difficulties</b>.</li>
	<li>Many people <b>experience</b> <b>difficulty</b> <b>in</b> sleeping at some time in their lives.</li>
	<li>The project <b>ran into difficulty</b> (=started to have difficulties) because of lack of money.</li>
	<li>This type of research <b>is</b> <b>fraught with difficulty</b> (=involves a lot of difficulties).</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>trouble</b> <i>noun</i> [uncountable and countable] a problem or several problems that make something difficult, spoil your plans etc:
<ul>
	<li>The <b>trouble</b> was <b>caused</b> by a loose wire.</li>
	<li>They <b>had</b> <b>trouble</b> finding the building where the meeting was held.</li>
	<li>Students of English often <b>have trouble with</b> phrasal verbs.</li>
	<li>The company <b>ran into trouble</b> (=started to have problems) when it tried to expand too quickly.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<p align="left"><b>STUDY NOTE: Grammar </b></p>
<b>Trouble</b> can be used either as an uncountable noun, for example:

They had a great deal of trouble with the new computer system or as a countable noun, for example: Teenagers often find it difficult to tell their parents about their <b>troubles</b>.

(=about the problems in their lives that are making them worried and unhappy)
<p align="left"></p>
<b>complication</b> <i>noun</i> [countable] an additional problem that makes a bad or difficult situation even harder to deal with than it already is:
<ul>
	<li>The project should finish in June, provided that there are no more <b>complications</b>.</li>
	<li>The surgeons knew it would be a difficult operation. A <b>further complication</b> (=another complication) was that the patient was in her 60s.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>setback</b> <i>noun</i> [countable] something that happens which stops you making progress or which makes things worse than they were before:
<ul>
	<li>The peace talks <b>suffered a major setback</b> when a bomb exploded outside the conference hotel.</li>
	<li>Despite some early <b>setbacks</b>, his campaign for the presidency was successful.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>obstacle</b> <i>noun</i> [countable] a difficult problem that stops someone or something making progress or developing:
<ul>
	<li>Criminal gangs are the <b>biggest obstacle to</b> democratic reform.</li>
	<li>The lack of child care is an enormous <b>obstacle to</b> women's participation in the work force.</li>
	<li>There are still some major technical obstacles to overcome (=to deal with).</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>pitfall</b> <i>noun</i> [countable] a problem that is likely to happen when you are doing something, especially one that is caused by a mistake that people often make:
<ul>
	<li>The book shows you how to <b>avoid</b> the usual <b>pitfalls</b> when you are at an interview.</li>
	<li>The most <b>common</b> <b>pitfall</b> when treating the disease is to give too much treatment too late.</li>
	<li>Financial advisers should explain to customers the <b>potential</b> <b>pitfalls</b> (=the problems that could happen) of investing in risky small company stocks.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>dilemma</b> <i>noun</i> [countable] a situation in which it is very difficult to decide what to do, because all the choices seem equally good or equally bad:
<ul>
	<li>The doctors were <b>faced with a moral dilemma</b>. Should they carry out the operation, when there was such a small chance of success?</li>
	<li>Kennedy <b>found himself in a dilemma over</b> Cuba. On the one hand he did not want to risk a nuclear war, but on the other he could not allow the Russians to place nuclear weapons so close to American soil.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>vicious circle</b> <i>noun</i> [singular] a situation in which one problem causes another problem, that then causes the first problem again, so that the whole process continues to be repeated:
<ul>
	<li>Some developing countries <b>get caught in a vicious circle</b>. They cannot afford to pay their debt repayments, and so the debts get even bigger.</li>
	<li>Stress at work can <b>create a vicious circle</b>. If you feel stressed and under pressure, you take longer to do your job, and because you take longer you become more stressed.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<p align="left"><b><i>2. Small problems </i></b></p>
<b>teething problems / troubles</b> <i>noun</i> [plural] small problems which happen when you start using or doing something new:
<ul>
	<li>With any computer system, there are likely to be one or two <b>teething problems</b> at first.</li>
	<li>There have been some <b>teething troubles</b> with the new rail service.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>hitch</b> <i>noun</i> [countable] a small problem when you are trying to do something:
<ul>
	<li>Everything went well on the first night of the play except for one or two <b>slight hitches</b> with the lighting.</li>
	<li>The plan <b>went off without a hitch</b>. (=There were no problems)</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>snag</b> <i>noun</i> [countable] a small problem or disadvantage, especially in something which is mainly good and satisfactory:
<ul>
	<li><b>The only snag</b> with going on holiday in Sweden is the cost.</li>
	<li>There are one or two little <b>snags</b> that needed to be <b>ironed out</b>. (=dealt with)</li>
	<li>Almost immediately after they began their research, they <b>hit</b> a series of <b>snags</b>. (=they had to deal with a number of small problems)</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<p align="left"><b>STUDY NOTE: Grammar </b></p>
<b>Hitch and snag</b> are informal words, and should not be used in formal essays.
<p align="left"></p>
<b><i>3. Solutions </i></b><b>solution</b> <i>noun</i> [countable] a way of dealing with a problem:
<ul>
	<li>Politicians have been trying to <b>find a solution to</b> the housing crisis for many years now.</li>
	<li>In this essay I shall consider the main causes of the problem of air pollution, and try to <b>put forward</b> (=suggest) some <b>possible solutions</b>.</li>
	<li>Unless scientists can <b>come up with a solution</b> (=think of a solution) quickly, we may soon run out of sources of energy.</li>
	<li>When people become too old to look after themselves, <b>the ideal solution</b> is for other members of their family to look after them.</li>
	<li>If you have difficulty sleeping, you need to identify the factors that are causing it and deal with them. That is the only <b>effective long-term solution</b>.</li>
	<li>There was no easy solution to Tom's problem. (=there was no easy way of dealing with it)</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>answer</b> <i>noun</i> [countable] a successful way of dealing with a problem or an unsatisfactory situation:
<ul>
	<li>Some people believe that the only <b>answer to</b> the problem of rising crime is to build more prisons.</li>
	<li>It would be mistaken to think that science and technology can always provide an <b>answer to</b> everything.</li>
	<li>There are <b>no easy answers to</b> the problem of teenage pregnancies.</li>
	<li>People have been struggling with this problem for a long time, but no one has yet <b>come up with an answer</b>. (=thought of an answer)</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>way out</b> <i>noun</i> [countable] a way of dealing with a very serious situation which you have become involved in:
<ul>
	<li>The president's advisors are trying to <b>find a way out of</b> the crisis.</li>
	<li>At first there seemed to be <b>no way out of</b> her difficulties.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>cure</b> <i>noun</i> [countable] a way of completely getting rid of a problem, especially one that affects many people in society, so that it does not happen again:
<ul>
	<li>The only <b>cure for</b> unemployment is to make it easier for companies to invest and create new jobs.</li>
	<li>Unfortunately, there is <b>no miracle cure</b> for inflation. (=there is nothing that will immediately make the situation better)</li>
	<li>Prison is not <b>a cure for all</b> social <b>ills</b>. (=a cure for all social problems)</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<p align="left"><b>STUDY NOTE: Grammar </b></p>
<b>Cure, remedy, prescription,</b> and <b>panacea</b> are used metaphorically to talk about dealing with problems. Their original meanings relate to treating illnesses.
<p align="left"></p>
<b>remedy</b> <i>noun</i> [countable] a possible way of dealing with a problem, especially using practical methods:
<ul>
	<li>Expensive hi-tech <b>remedies</b> are often useless to poor countries.</li>
	<li>A number of <b>remedies</b> have been suggested, but so far none of them has shown itself to be effective.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>prescription</b> <i>noun</i> [countable] something that someone suggests as a way of dealing with a problem:
<ul>
	<li>Their <b>prescription for</b> dealing with poverty in Africa is to encourage more trade, instead of increasing aid.</li>
	<li>The socialists' main <b>prescription for</b> any social problem seems to be to pump more and more money into the system.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>panacea</b> <i>noun</i> [countable] a formal word, meaning something that people hope will solve all their problems. You use <b>panacea</b> when you doubt that something can really do this:
<ul>
	<li>The law is not a <b>universal panacea</b>. (=it cannot solve all our problems)</li>
	<li>Some people think that free market capitalism is a <b>panacea for all our ills</b>. (=something that will solve all our problems)</li>
	<li>Furthermore, industrialization has rarely been the <b>panacea for</b> rural poverty that had been hoped.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>quick fix</b> <i>noun</i> [countable] a quick way of dealing with a problem, which usually only works for a short time. You use <b>quick fix</b> especially when you think that people need to find a more permanent solution:
<ul>
	<li>There is no <b>quick fix</b> to defeat terrorism.</li>
	<li>A leading scientist has warned that <b>quick fix schemes</b> to deal with global warming could potentially be more damaging than the problem itself.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<p align="left"><b>STUDY NOTE: Grammar </b></p>
<b>Quick fix</b> is an informal phrase, and should not be used in formal essays.
<p align="left"></p>
<b>magic bullet</b> <i>noun</i> [countable] something that solves a difficult problem quickly and simply. You use <b>magic bullet</b> especially when saying that it will be difficult to find such a solution:
<ul>
	<li>There is no <b>magic bullet</b> <b>for</b> dealing with inflation.</li>
	<li>Although a <b>magic bullet</b> <b>for</b> curing cancer is still not likely any time soon, researchers are making slow and steady progress.</li>
</ul>
<h1>Quoting People</h1>
<h2>Quoting People</h2>
<p align="left"><b><i>Ways of quoting what someone has said </i></b></p>
<b>say</b> <i>verb</i> [transitive] used when quoting what someone said in a speech, or wrote in a book, article etc:
<ul>
	<li>John F. Kennedy once famously <b>said</b> "Ask not what your country can do for you. Ask what you can do for your country."</li>
	<li>In their report, they <b>say that</b> they see no reason to change the existing system.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<p align="left"><b>STUDY NOTE: Grammar </b></p>
<b>Say</b> is used a lot in English. Below are other words and expressions which mean the same thing, and when writing essays it is a good idea to use some of these instead of repeating <b>say</b> every time.
<p align="left"></p>
<b>write</b> <i>verb</i> [transitive] used when quoting what someone wrote in a book, article etc:
<ul>
	<li>Du Bois <b>wrote that</b> the United States was "a land of magnificent possibilities - the home of noble souls and generous people."</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>point out</b> <i>phrasal verb</i> to mention something in a book, article etc, which seems particularly important and relevant:
<ul>
	<li>Dr Graham <b>points out</b> <b>that</b> "All normal children show some degree of antisocial behaviour".</li>
	<li><b>As</b> Rachel Carson <b>points out</b> in her book "Silent Spring", chemicals used in farming are having a devastating effect on our countryside.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<p align="left"><b>STUDY NOTE: Grammar </b></p>
You use <b>As</b> ... <b>points out/notes/states</b> etc to show that you agree with what the writer has said.
<p align="left"></p>
<b>note / remark</b> <i>verb</i> [transitive] to say that you have noticed that something is true.

<b>Note</b> and <b>remark</b> are formal words:
<ul>
	<li>Lyons (1977) <b>notes that</b> not all languages have tenses.</li>
	<li><b>As</b> Brownmiller <b>has remarked</b>, women, on the whole, have not achieved economic equality with men in our society.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>observe</b> <i>verb</i> [transitive] to say that you have noticed that something is true. <b>Observe</b> is used when reporting someone's scientific studies, or when saying that someone points out a truth about life or the world:
<ul>
	<li>Winnicott <b>observed that</b> mothers spend much of the first few months imitating their infants.</li>
	<li><b>As</b> Joseph Heller once <b>observed</b>, success and failure can be equally difficult to deal with.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>state</b> <i>verb</i> [transitive] used when saying what people, reports, laws and rules say. State sounds very definite and full of authority:
<ul>
	<li>Parkinson's Law <b>states that</b> "work expands to fill the time available".</li>
	<li><b>As</b> Skinner (1948) <b>states</b>, verbal behaviour develops according to the same principles as any other behaviour.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>argue</b> <i>verb</i> [transitive] used when you want to say that someone puts forward a set of ideas:
<ul>
	<li>Rousseau <b>argued</b> <b>that</b> all men were born equal.</li>
	<li><b>As</b> Edward Said <b>argues</b>: European culture gained in strength and identity by setting itself off against the Orient (Said 1995).</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>conclude</b> <i>verb</i> [transitive] used when you are introducing the end of what someone has written, especially when it is a summary of the main point of what they wrote:
<ul>
	<li>Wagner <b>concludes that</b> managers should constantly try to lower costs and achieve high product quality.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>claim</b> <i>verb</i> [transitive] you use <b>claim</b> when you are saying what someone has said, and you do not believe that what they said was true or you think there is no proof for what they said:
<ul>
	<li>Some people have <b>claimed that</b> Kennedy was killed by the CIA.</li>
	<li>Doctors <b>claimed to have</b> found a cure for the disease.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>according to...</b>  <i>preposition</i> used when saying what people, organizations, and reports have said:
<ul>
	<li><b>According to</b> a recent survey by Time magazine, 49 percent of Americans said they thought the President was doing a good job.</li>
	<li>Young children need at least ten hours of sleep a day, <b>according to</b> Dr. Shaefer.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>in the words of</b> ... used when saying exactly what someone has said, especially when this seems to sum up a situation very well:
<ul>
	<li><b>In the words of</b> one professor, the object of teaching English literature is not to pass on knowledge, but to train the imagination.</li>
</ul>
<h1>Reffering</h1>
<h2>Reffering</h2>
<ol>
	<li>Referring to an earlier part of an essay, report etc</li>
	<li>Referring to a later part of an essay, report etc</li>
	<li>Referring to another piece of work</li>
</ol>
<p align="left"></p>
<p align="left"><b><i>1. Referring to an earlier part of an essay, report etc </i></b></p>
<b>above</b> <i>adjective</i>, <i>adverb</i> used when referring to something in an earlier part of the essay, report etc that you are writing, usually something that is nearby and on the same page:
<ul>
	<li>See <b>the above</b> diagram.</li>
	<li>Students often have difficulty with verbs of motion, as <b>the above</b> example shows.</li>
	<li>This procedure is described <b>above</b>.</li>
	<li>For more information, <b>see above</b>.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<p align="left"><b>STUDY NOTE: Grammar </b></p>
<b>Above</b> can be used as an adjective, for example: the <b>above</b> picture, or as an adverb, for example: see <b>above</b>.
<p align="left"></p>
<b>previous</b> <i>adjective</i> [only before noun] a <b>previous</b> part of an essay, report etc comes before this one:
<ul>
	<li>The results of this study were discussed in <b>a previous</b> section. (=one of the sections before this one)</li>
	<li>As was mentioned in <b>the previous </b>chapter, (=the chapter immediately before this one) these changes occurred over a long period of time.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>preceding</b> <i>adjective</i> [only before noun] the <b>preceding</b> part of an essay, report etc comes immediately before this one:
<ul>
	<li>In <b>the preceding</b> pages, she describes the history of the island.</li>
	<li>These meetings were mentioned in <b>the preceding</b> paragraph.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>earlier</b> <i>adverb</i> at some point before this in an essay, report etc:
<ul>
	<li>It is extremely important, therefore, to follow the general principles on project planning that we described <b>earlier in </b>the chapter.</li>
	<li><b>As was mentioned earlier</b>, at that time most people could not expect to live beyond the age of 65.</li>
	<li><b>As outlined earlier</b>, an alternative theory was becoming widely accepted in the 1920s. <b>as has been seen/it has been seen that</b> used when referring to something that you have already mentioned or shown:</li>
	<li>Matisse, <b>as has been seen</b>, was inspired by the work of Cezanne.</li>
	<li><b>It has been seen that</b> there are a number of problems with this type of approach.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>the former</b> <i>adj n</i> [singular] a formal phrase meaning the first of the two things or people that you have just mentioned:
<ul>
	<li><b>The former</b> method is probably more likely to produce a successful result.</li>
	<li>There were two possible ways of dealing with the situation: try to negotiate with the terrorists, or launch an immediate attack. The government chose <b>the former</b>.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<p align="left"><b>STUDY NOTE: Grammar </b></p>
<b>Former</b> can be used as an adjective, for example: <b>the former</b> approach, or as a noun, for example: The corporation chose <b>the former</b>.
<p align="left"></p>
<b>the latter</b> <i>adj n</i> [singular] a formal phrase meaning the second of the two things or people that you have just mentioned:
<ul>
	<li>Some people think the killing was deliberate. Others say that it was an accident. I would take <b>the latter</b> view.</li>
	<li>The people are either Albanians or Serbs. <b>The latter</b> regard Kosovo as a sacred part of historic Serbia.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<p align="left"><b>STUDY NOTE: Grammar </b></p>
<b>Latter</b> can be used as an adjective, for example: <b>the latter</b> view, or as a noun, for example: Wilson preferred <b>the latter</b>.
<p align="left"></p>
<p align="left"><b><i>2. Referring to a later part of an essay, report etc </i></b></p>
<b>below</b> <i>adverb</i> used when referring to a later part of the essay, report etc that you are writing, usually nearby on the same page:
<ul>
	<li><b>See below</b> for further details.</li>
	<li>The reasons that lay behind this decision are discussed <b>below</b>.</li>
	<li><b>Below</b> is a short account of the events that led up to the crisis.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>the following</b> <i>adj n</i> [singular] used when referring to the things or people that you are going to mention:
<ul>
	<li>Consider <b>the following</b> example.</li>
	<li>It is important to remember <b>the following</b> points.</li>
	<li>Make sure that the patient has <b>the following</b>: drugs, dressings, X rays, and a completed appointment card.</li>
	<li>The following are some of the things that people said about the book.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<p align="left"><b>STUDY NOTE: Grammar </b></p>
<b>The following</b> can be used as an adjective, for example: <b>the following</b> method, or as a noun, for example: Choose one of <b>the following</b>.

When it introduces a list that comes immediately after it, <b>the following</b> has a colon after it: <i>Your report should discuss the following: initial hypothesis; the experiment; analysis of the results. </i>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>as follows</b> used when introducing a list or an explanation:
<ul>
	<li>The three elements are <b>as follows:</b> economy, efficiency, and effectiveness.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>there follows</b> used when giving a short description of what comes next in an essay, report etc:
<ul>
	<li><b>There follows</b> a simple example of this kind of organization of ideas and information.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>over page / overleaf</b> <i>adverb</i> on the next page. Used when telling people to look at the next page for more information about something:
<ul>
	<li>This sound is produced with the tongue behind the top teeth (see diagram <b>over page</b>).</li>
	<li>More than 8,400 new airliners will be sold over the next 15 years, worth more than $500 billion (see chart <b>overleaf</b>).</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>see over</b> used when asking people to look at the next page for more information about something:
<ul>
	<li>For more information, <b>see over</b>.</li>
	<li>Einstein was awarded the Nobel prize for his work on the Quantum Theory (<b>see over</b>).</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>as we shall see</b> used when saying that something will be explained or become clear later in a piece of writing:
<ul>
	<li><b>As we shall see later</b>, their views differ in several important respects.</li>
	<li>This idea is probably wrong, <b>as we shall see</b>.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<p align="left"></p>
<p align="left"></p>
<p align="left"></p>
<p align="left"><b><i>3. Referring to another piece of work </i></b></p>
<b>see</b> <i>verb</i> [transitive] used when referring to another writer's work:
<ul>
	<li>For a more extensive discussion, <b>see</b> Eysenck (1979).</li>
	<li><b>See</b> Townsend (1971, pp. 120–9) for an interesting analyis of this topic.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>as somebody says / notes / remarks / points out</b> etc used when you are quoting another writer, when you agree with what they said:
<ul>
	<li><b>As</b> Professor Richard Dawkins <b>points out</b>, this process is influenced by environmental factors.</li>
	<li>It is important to remember, <b>as</b> Alan Kay <b>says</b>, "the main difference between scientists and engineers is that engineers want to make things and scientists want to understand them."</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>cf.</b> used when referring to something, for example a particular writer's work, that is connected with the subject that you are writing about:
<ul>
	<li>Often a male speaker will use a more formal style when addressing a woman (<b>cf.</b></li>
</ul>
Trudgill 1986).
<ul>
	<li>Very few linguists have produced analyses that make use of such functional categories (but <b>cf.</b> Halliday, 1973).</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<p align="left"><b>STUDY NOTE: Grammar </b></p>
<b>Cf.</b> is the abbreviation of the Latin word confer, which means 'compare'.
<p align="left"></p>
<b>op. cit.</b> used in formal writing when you are referring to a book, article etc that you have already mentioned:
<ul>
	<li>There has been much discussion concerning the origins of primitive art (see also Gombrich, <b>op. cit</b>., p63-94)</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<p align="left"><b>STUDY NOTE: Grammar </b></p>
<b>Op. cit.</b> is the abbreviation of the Latin words <b>opere citato</b>, which mean 'in the work that I have quoted'.
<p align="left"></p>
<b>ibid.</b> <i>adverb</i> used in formal writing when you are referring to the same book, article etc as the one that you have just mentioned:
<ul>
	<li>Half of these countries have incomes between $1,000 and $3,000 ( <b>ibid:</b> p63).</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"><b> </b></p>
<p align="left"><b>STUDY NOTE: Grammar </b></p>
<b>Ibid.</b> comes from the Latin word <b>ibidem</b>, which means <b>'in the same place'</b>.
<p align="left"></p>
<b>loc. cit.</b> used in formal writing when you are referring to the same page in a book, article etc as the one that you have just mentioned:
<ul>
	<li>According to Dionysius (<b>loc. cit.)</b> the statue had disappeared, and was supposed to have been burned.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<p align="left"></p>
<p align="left"></p>
<p align="left"><b>STUDY NOTE: Grammar </b></p>
<b>loc. cit.</b> is an abbreviation of the Latin words <b>loco citato</b>, which mean 'in the same place I have quoted'.
<p align="left"></p>
<b>pp.</b> the written abbreviation of <b>pages</b>, used when you are referring to several pages in another writer's book, article etc:

• See also Wadsworth 1978, pp. 54-55
<h1>Related / Unrelated</h1>
<h2>Related / Unrelated</h2>
<ol>
	<li>Ways of saying that two things are related</li>
	<li>Related to what is being discussed</li>
	<li>Not related</li>
	<li>Not related to what you are discussing</li>
</ol>
<p align="left"></p>
<p align="left"><b><i>1. Ways of saying that two things are related </i></b></p>
<b>related / connected</b> <i>adjective</i> if two things are <b>related</b> or <b>connected</b>, there is some kind of connection between them:
<ul>
	<li>These two problems are <b>closely related to</b> each other.</li>
	<li>Some people think that the stones are <b>connected</b> in some way <b>with</b> religious ceremonies.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<p align="left"><b>STUDY NOTE: Grammar </b></p>
You can use <b>related</b> before a noun, for example: The report deals with homelessness and other <b>related issues</b>. But you do not normally use <b>connected</b> before a noun in this way.

You can also say that two things are <b>not unrelated</b> (=they are related), for example:

Much of modern philosophy is <b>not unrelated to</b> the ideas of the ancient Greeks.
<p align="left"></p>
<b>linked</b> <i>adjective</i> if two things <b>are linked</b>, there is a direct connection between them, and often one of them is the cause of the other:
<ul>
	<li>High levels of cholesterol are <b>linked with</b> an increased risk of heart disease.</li>
	<li>Individual performance is <b>linked to</b> the amount of effort that you put in.</li>
	<li>Two <b>closely linked</b> factors produced this result.</li>
	<li>Our minds and our bodies are <b>inextricably linked</b>. (=they are so closely linked that they cannot be considered separately)</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>(there is a) connection / link</b> if there is a <b>connection</b> or <b>link</b> between two things, they are dircetly connected, and often one of them is the cause of the other:
<ul>
	<li>All the data we have suggests that <b>there is a direct connection between</b> the use of fossil fuels and the rise in global temperatures.</li>
	<li>Studies in the 1960s showed that <b>there was a link between</b> smoking and lung cancer.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>(there is a) correlation</b> if there is a <b>correlation</b> between two things, they are connected and one may cause the other:
<ul>
	<li>Karimov claims to have discovered a <b>direct correlation between</b> nuclear tests in the area and earthquakes throughout the former Soviet Union.</li>
	<li>It is is well known that <b>there is a strong correlation between</b> obesity and some forms of cancer.</li>
	<li>Numerous studies have shown a consistent <b>negative correlation between</b> age and participation in sporting activities. (=older people are less likely to do sport) |  <b>There is a</b> significant <b>positive correlation between</b> alcohol consumption and the incidence of the disease. (=people who drink a lot of alcohol are more likely to get the disease)</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<p align="left"><b>STUDY NOTE: Grammar </b></p>
<b>Correlation</b> is used especially in statements that are based on scientific studies and statistics
<p align="left"></p>
<b>Interrelated / interconnected</b> <i>adjective</i> if things are <b>interrelated</b> or interconnected, they are connected with each other and affect each other in a complicated series of ways:
<ul>
	<li>Darwin said that all life on earth is <b>interrelated</b>.</li>
	<li>The book consists of a series of <b>interconnected</b> essays.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>interdependent</b> <i>adjective</i> if two things are <b>interdependent</b>, each of them depends on the other, and they cannot exist or continue independently:
<ul>
	<li>The parts of any living organism are <b>interdependent</b>.</li>
	<li>The economies of town and countryside were closely <b>interdependent</b>.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>associated</b> <i>adjective</i> if something is <b>associated</b> with another thing, it is thought to have a connection with it:
<ul>
	<li>Researchers discovered a gene <b>associated with</b> some forms of skin cancer.</li>
	<li>Salaries and <b>associated</b> costs have risen significantly over the past year.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>be bound up with</b> if two things <b>are bound up with</b> each other, they are very closely connected and need to be considered together:
<ul>
	<li>Your sense of yourself as a person <b>is closely bound up with</b> what happens in your early childhood.</li>
	<li>The mill's history is <b>inextricably bound up</b> with that of the Wilkins family (=they are so closely linked that they cannot be considered separately)</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>go together</b> <i>phrasal verb</i> if two things <b>go together</b>, you usually find one with the other:
<ul>
	<li>Ignorance and distrust <b>go together.</b></li>
	<li>Inflation and high unemployment usually <b>go together</b>.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<p align="left"><b><i>2. Related to what is being discussed </i></b></p>
<b>relevant</b> <i>adjective</i> related to what is being discussed or to a particular area of activity:
<ul>
	<li>His work is particularly <b>relevant to</b> this discussion.</li>
	<li>The tribunal will look at all the <b>relevant</b> facts before making up its mind.</li>
	<li>Applicants should be educated to PhD level, and have several years' <b>relevant experience. </b></li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>pertinent</b> <i>adjective</i> a formal word. If something is <b>pertinent to</b> what is being discussed, it is directly concerned with it and it is important to consider it:
<ul>
	<li>The report was first published in the late 1980s, but its findings are still <b>pertinent to</b> today's situation.</li>
	<li>This raises a <b>pertinent question</b>. Why should we give politicians all this power?</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>germane</b> <i>adjective</i> a formal word. Something that is <b>germane</b> is directly concerned with what is being discussed:
<ul>
	<li>The chapters which are <b>germane</b> <b>to</b> to the topic are chapters 11 and 12.</li>
	<li>These questions are especially <b>germane</b> in nuclear physics, where researchers are constantly looking for better methods of analysis.</li>
</ul>
<p align="left"></p>
<b>have a bearing on</b> if something <b>has a bearing on</b> a situation, it is likely to have a big effect on it and it is important to consider it:
<ul>
	<li>At first it was difficult to see how this discovery <b>had</b> any <b>bearing on</b> the problem.</li>
